fields.comments:
Ivo: Story partly similar to The Sign of the Cross.

Maria: draws on other elements from paintings and book illustrations to display Roman decadence (not just religious traditions). The connection ivo makes visually to book illustrations for the Polish novel Quo vadis (Ulpiano Checa, Nero's banquet) is interesting. Because it helps us see the degree to which this film replicates the story line of that novel (Roman soldier pursues girl but is eventually baptised into her faith). And the similar plotline for a British play Sign of the Cross that was made into an American film in 1914. These similarities suggest we should also explore national differences in the presentation of these tales of conversion and martyrdom (not least because of the Catholic context of Italian film production v Anglo-Protestant in USA or secular in France). Two further aspects of the film deserve particular attention. The use of location shooting to show the exterior of the prison in which the Christian community is placed. How it gives a topographical authenticity to the fictional narrative. And its use of special effects to display religious visions of angels and the cross. This strategy was particularly useful for cinema when it was frequently charged with immorality, because the distinctive strategies of the medium itself could be shown at work to construct an instructive story of spiritual salvation for its audiences.

FG: Christie. Why does it end with the vision? is the ending missing or are we meant to end here without the martyrdoms, angelic vision - looks alot like the angels that appear at annunication in the Life of Christ (door opens like has entered room). issue of narrativising visions (the clincher is the 'real' vision to persuade him, after so much dumb show). role of the cross as a means to show early Christianity. this seems very baroque Catholic and would be difficult for UK and US audiences. How does QV narrative and analogy w Russian occupation play out in other countries in 20thc c? And in context of secular Italy?  Doreen: analogy with compare lantern slides & medium's idea of projection. theologically makes something invisible visible and part of process of persuading the audience to belief, also about surfaces can show projections. suggests audience familiar with this kind of process and seen it before in 19th c traditions. Issue of censorship might determine what aspects of martrydom you can show? Penz: artificality of angel matched by artificiality of the prison set. contrasts sharply with the outdoor shots. Also beautifully photographed organic shot of entry to catacomb as a black hole. 

Michael Williams:  I was intrigued by the location Maria foregrounded in From Love to Martyrdom, that of the prison, which seems to be a ruin of an ancient site of some kind. Do we know where it is? Did audiences at the time, or did they have it explained to them in the way that ‘actual’ locations are marshalled into a discourse of authenticity? That theme of ‘topographical authenticity’, as Maria put it, is a fascinating one. The ruin also looks like a ruin, and while there were obviously ruins in antiquity too, it’s an interesting choice in terms of the presentation of the past and choices about what looks ‘new’ in a context, and what needs to seem authentic and old – that aspect of patina. The set of the interior of that prison is made to look somewhat old, with some painted cracks, but perhaps seems more intact that the exterior might suggest (I remember that the prison seen in Pompeian Martyr had much newer looking cells with their painted bricks). The theme of authenticity, what a representation needs to seem authentic to to be accepted by audiences (what their cultural and historical horizon of understanding is – what they will compare a given film to), is an important one.

where is this?

religious vision

Ivo: Eric Moormann has consulted a Roman expert in ancient Roman aquaducts, Valerio Astolfi (Sapienza), for the identification of the shots in the BFI print of Dall'amore al martiro, in which the actors enter or exit what is supposed to be a prison but looks like an ancient aquaduct.  I have thought about the Ponte Lupo at the Aqua Marcia, but it does't coincide exactly. Astolfi thinks of the Mandrione, where the aquaducts Felice, Claudio and Marcio coincide. Yet, he doesn't exclude a place somewhere at the actual Parco Archeologico. Below, some pictures of the Mandrione:

Ivo: This film from 1910 sometimes re-uses the exact same scenography (sets and props) as the earlier (1908) Cines film La rivale (Cineteca di Bologna), cf.below pictures from La rivale and Dall'amore al martirio.

 

La rivale (Cines, 1908)                                                Dall amore al martirio (Cines, 1910)

fields.title: Elektra (Original) 523
fields.synopsis: From the Greek myth. Agamemnon lies dying, murdered by his wife Clytemnestra. Before he is sent away from the palace, Orestes is begged by his sister Elektra to avenge their father one day. She waits ten years for him. On his return, she takes him to where Clytemnestra is sleeping. As he deliberates, armed guards force their way in. Orestes defeats them in swordplay and then kills his mother. Next, he kills her lover Aegisthus. Elektra and Orestes display the two dead bodies to the crowd outside the palace. (565ft)
fields.cast:
Mary Fuller: Elektra

Among the extras is Florence Turner. NB Maurice Costello is mentioned in sources such as Silent Era, but older sources don't mention him and neither Steve Massa nor Ivo Blom have recognized him in the film.

fields.comments:
Maria: Antigone looks more complex than this.

Ivo: Yes, a bit, although there were several paintings. Indicative are the scrolls on the painting, while we see a container with scrolls in the film. 

By the way, I think I have identified Elektra. It is the Aquila production Elettra (1909, based on Sophocles' tragedy, 265 metres, 7 acts). It has exactly the same intertitles but then in German as the ones listed in Bernardini''s first volume of Il cinema muto italiano, 1905-1909, p. 289. The only thing that lacks is the first scene: Clytaemnestra pushes her lover Aegisthus to kill her husband Agamemnon. The film starts just after the second title: The death of Agamemnon. As very few Aquila films remain, this is very interesting. In the BFI list it was indicated as possibly American, ca. 1910.

Ivo: On second thought, this could also be the Vitagraph version of Elektra (J. Stuart Blackton, 1910), mentioned in William Uricchio & Roberta Pearson, Reframing Culture: The Case of the Vitagraph Quality Films, p. 62. Here the film's publicity refers to the earlier opera. So, an American film after all. According to IMDB, leads were for Maurice Costello as ? and Mary Fuller as Elektra; it was her debut. Yet, I don't recognize Costello in this print.The Vitagraph version was 301 m. long, was released 8 April 1910, and based on the Richard Strauss opera. See Paolo Cherchi Usai ed., Vitagraph Co. of America: Il cinema prima di Hollywood, p. 465. Italian Wikipedia claims this is a lost film. Photos in American archives may help to identify this film. See also http://www.silentera.com/PSFL/data/E/Elektra1910.html

Ivo: PS many pictorial predecessors to the film but none very close to its imagery, and of course the film doesn't show the famous chase of Orestes by the Furies.

 Bernardino Mei, Orestes Slaying Clytemnestra, 1655, private collection

 

 

 

 

 

 John Collier, Clytaemnestra, 1882. Interesting is that she is depicted with a dagger or axe, but in the film her husband seems to have been killed by poison. As we miss a part of the film it is difficult to tell. Also, in Greek mythology he was killed in his bed, not at a crowded banquet as in the film. Similar to the scene in Agrippina, immediately pointing out Nero as the new emperor, in the film Elettra the queen immediately appoints her lover as the new king. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  John Collier, 1914

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

J.H. Tischbein, Electra recognizing Orestes at Agamemnon's grave. NB the return of Orestes was painted by many. The meeting at the tomb was already depicted on Greek pottery.

 

 

 

 

 

Frederick Leighton, Electra at Agamemnon's Grave, c. 1869

fields.title: Esclave de Phidias, L' (Original) 348024
fields.alt_titles: The Slave of Phydias (Alternative), Slaves of Phydias (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: Ancient Athens. The devotion of a slave girl, Callyce, to her master, the sculptor Phydias, takes her into exile with him. Rl.1. [Lacks initial section]. Sculptor Phydias searches for a divine model for a statue of Venus. Callyce, his slave girl, is in love with him, but her advances are rejected until she makes an offering of love flowers to one of the deities. Phydias embraces her, but their passionate encounter is seen by the sculptor's wife, Quinta. She has Callyce beaten, but Phydias saves her from further punishment. Quinta then steals the sacred gold set aside for the proposed statue of Venus and publicly accuses her husband of the theft. He is arrested. Callyce goes in search of him, playing her lyre (1617ft). Rl.2. From his prison cell Phydias hears her music. He is sentenced to exile. Quinta meanwhile watches a display of dancing by slave girls. Phydias is led into exile by a mounted guard of soldiers, followed by the faithful Callyce, who succours him when he collapses. At nightfall, by the sea, he bids farewell to Greece and is embraced by Callyce. On a boat, they approach Elide, the road of oblivion. Finis (789ft). (2406ft) (Shortlist) [Synopsis, viewing copy] Melkios sends Phydias a letter commissioning the carving of a statue of Venus for the Temple of the Goddesses. Phydias searches for a Divine Model for the statue. Callyce, the slave girl he selects, is in love with him but her advances are rejected. Callyce attempts to please him by picking his favourite flowers. Returning to the studio she spies Phydias with Quinta. Disheartened, Callyce takes the flowers as a love offering to a statue of a deity (End Reel One). Phydias hears Callyce playing her lyre in the gardens. He is enamoured. Phydias embraces Callyce but their encounter is seen by Quinta. Later, Quinta's affections are rejected by Phydias. She plans her vengeance. Quinta has Callyce beaten, but Phydias intervenes. Quinta then steals the gold payment for the statue of Venus and publicly accuses Phydias of the theft. Phydias is arrested. Callyce searches for him. playing her lyre. From his prison cell, Phydias hears her music and climbs to the window to see her. Meanwhile, Quinta hosts a party and watches a display of dancing slave girls. Phydias is sentenced to exile and is led away by a mounted guard of soldiers. Followed by the faithful Callyce, Phydias is comforted when he collapses. At nightfall, by the sea, Phydias bids farewell to Greece and is embraced by Callyce. They board a boat to Elide, the road of oblivion. End title (End Reel Two). (Synopsis)

fields.title: Excursions Aux Ruines Romaines D'Ampurias (Original) 13878
fields.alt_titles: Ein Ausflug In Die Romanischen Ruinen Von Ampurias (Alternative), Trip to the Roman Ruins of Ampurias (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: The Roman ruins at Ampurias in the Gulf de Rosas in North Eastern Spain. A number of views of the Roman ruins which have been excavated. Shots of the archaeologists at work on the site (89). CU the finds; a piece of stone with writing on and some coins. Pan of a harbour with boats. Waves seen breaking on a breakwater and various shots of waves breaking on a rocky shore (249ft). (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Maria: A number of views of the Roman ruins that have been excavated at Empúries in the Gulf de Rosas in North-Eastern Spain. Shots of a hunter with his dogs and an archaeologist accompanied by labourers arriving and working on the site. Close ups of some finds, including a fragment of inscribed stone and some coins. Away from the excavations, a pan of the harbour with boats and fishermen. Various shots of rough waves breaking on a breakwater and rocky shore. Ends with long shot of local town and shoreline. raises question of how one ancient site might be coded compared to another. This French trip to Ampurias shows some similarities with the British Visit to Pompeii – panning shots of ruins, an archaeologist with his labourers, display of finds. But emptier than Pompeii. The site only an element of the film (despite the title). [Ruins of a Roman military camp (walls, mosaics, amphitheatre, Christian basilica) built on remains of a Greek trading port, and by the sea.]  Interest shown in distinctive setting by the sea and proximity to town, allowing for contrast of past & present, stasis & movement.

Ivo (on viewing the BFI print): Indeed, the contrast between the wild sea (quite long takes of the breakers) and the stasis of the ruins beforehand is very striking. Interesting use of humans to indicate the scale of things.

fields.title: Fedra (Original) 409926
fields.synopsis: Ancient Greece: Phaedra, wife of Theseus, loves her stepson Hippolytus. Repulsed, she falsely accuses him. He drives off in his chariot and is killed. His innocence is revealed. She kills herself. "KRIEGSERKLÄRUNG" [declaration of war]. "FEST ZU THESEUS RÜCKKEHR" [a feast for Theseus' return] (10). A columned hall with two maidservants and about 10 men and women drinking and toasting (17). The palace porch with 4 columns and, beyond, battlements and a view of an acropolis. Two servants carry across the corpse of Hippolytus followed by Aricie, his beloved (28). Open country: Hippolytus approaches and mounts an elaborate horse drawn chariot (43). The porch: Hippolytus sits head in hand. Enter the bearded Theseus. They joyfully embrace and enter the palace (54). Phaedra in her bedroom: detailed furniture, square columns supporting a curtained rail, wall frieze. Theseus and Hippolytus enter and Theseus embraces her. She denounces Hippolytus. He denies, pleads, kneels. Theseus curses him and he leaves. Phaedra, pleased, embraces Theseus (91). In the porch, the distraught Hippolytus tells Aricie what has happened (104). The unhappy young couple walk in front of a rocky waterfall. Aricie alone in the same setting (110). "HIPPOLITUS TOD" [Hippolytus' death] (111). Phaedra alone and unhappy in her bedchamber (113). Hippolitus and Aricie stroll happily in front of a stream, rocks and trees (127). Phaedra in front of a semicircular waterfall and an arcade, filmed at Tivoli (128)."PHADRAS ANKLAGE GEGEN HIPPOLITUS. THESUS FLUCH" [Phaedra's accusation against Hippolytus. Theseus' curse]. (128ft) Notes: Incomplete. Nitrate damage. Originally 968ft. Sections missing and in wrong order. (Shotlist)

fields.title: Fille du centurion, La (Original) 412469
fields.alt_titles: Die Tochter des Centurio (Alternative), The Centurion's Daughter (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: The slave and daughter of a centurion become Christians in Rome. Main title and credits (13). The slaves of the centurion Vicinius attend to their duties. They prepare themselves for his arrival. The daughter of Vicinius is in love with a slave and they meet later. However, the slave must leave for another destination, which he keeps a secret. The daughter follows him and comes upon a Christian meeting led by St. Peter(?) and attended by the slave. Later the slaves are at work but no-one can find the Christian slave. The centurion demands to know where he is and why he is not attending to his duties. When found, the centurion orders him to be whipped, despite pleas for mercy from his daughter. The slave is taken off by the soldiers and whipped by the slave-master. After the beating the other slaves try to help him but they too are beaten by the slave-master. The slave is left for dead. The daughter comes to his aid and takes him to the caves where she saw St. Peter preaching. There she meets St. Peter and with the help of her lover is accepted into the Christian faith and baptised. At the house the centurion receives a message from the emperor ordering the arrest of the Christians, he orders his troops into action. The daughter and slave hear the news and make off for the caves in order to warn the other Christians. The Christians at prayer (694ft). Incomplete. Note: German titles. (Shotlist)

fields.title: Giulio Cesare (Original) 22080
fields.synopsis: The rise and fall of Julius Caesar. Calpurnia welcomes her husband, the triumphant Caesar back to Rome. Caesar, confiding his tyrannical aspirations to Mark Anthony, is overheard by Brutus, who remonstrates with him. Notwithstanding the opposition of Brutus and his friends, Mark Anthony obtains from the Senate a triumph and the crowning of Caesar. After the triumphal procession has passed, the conspirators Brutus and his friends are overheard by a spy. Calpurnia wakes from dreams of disaster for Caesar, and receives the spy's news of the conspiracy. She warns Caesar but he refuses to listen and attends the Senate. After Caesar's death at the hands of the conspirators, Mark Anthony rouses the people against them and they are driven from Rome. Brutus, waiting at Philippi, sees Caesar's ghost. The battle rages until Brutus is defeated and kills himself (644ft). Note: Incomplete. English intertitles. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Ivo: Is there still a tinted nitrate? Would be interesting to compare with other Caesar films, as BFI also has the Vitagraph version Julius Caesar and Bruto, and Eye has Guazzoni's 1914 feature Caio Giulio Cesare. 

Caesar returning from Gaul. Very much the same set as in Principessa e schiava (BFI, both Itala, 1909, also same leading actress, Adriana Costamagna, who worked at Itala in 1909-1911. Emilio Vardannes also acts in both Giulio Cesare and Principessa e schiava. As, according to Bernardini (Il cinema muto italiano, Vol. 1905/09), Princpessa e schiava was released in May 1909 and Giulio Cesare in September 1909, it is most likely that the sets were first built for Principessa e schiava and afterward used again for Giulio Cesare.

 

Giulio Cesare

Principessa e schiava. Same architecture with door left, curtain beneath hemicircle opening, and on the right wall with decoration of ram's head with garland. Even same prop of buste of Homer-like head, but on different pedestal.

Ivo: Former identifications of actors were wrong and incomplete. Bruto is played by Emilio Vardannes and not Luigi Mele. Giovanni Pastrone does not act in the film. Together with Gianna Chiapello (ex-Museo Nazionale del Cinema) I identified the right names. I have now added the right names above. [Aylin, can you activate the names?]

Ivo: Painting: The murder of Caesar is a bit similar to the painting by Georges Rochegrosse.

Georges-Antoine Rochegrosse, La Curée (1887, Musée de Grenoble)

fields.title: Heliogabale (Original) 362027
fields.synopsis: The abduction of a Vestal Virgin by the Emperor Heliogabalus leads to his overthrow. Heliogabalus arrives arm-in-arm with two of his court favourites to witness a sacrifice by the Chief Priest. He is attracted to the Vestal Virgin, Julia Aquilina Severa, but his advances to her are checked by the Chief Priest. The Emperor returns with force to knock the Chief Priest out of the way and enter the temple. He abducts Julia as she prays before the sacred flame, thereby outraging the watching populace. At an orgy at his palace he attempts to rape her, but is thwarted by insurrectionists who burst into the room. Heliogabalus flees through a trapdoor leading to the sewer, but is captured. His appeal to Julia for mercy is met by an averted face, and the mob prepares to throw him into the Tiber (484ft). Incomplete. Note: According to the Borromäum Catalogue this is the Eclair production. However it has been identified as the 1910 Film D'Art production. See also LAST DAYS OF HELIOGABALUS reviewed in The Bioscope 2/6/1910 p. 35. (Shotlist)

EYE

fields.comments:
Ivo: Indeed the Eye film by Feuillade is a completely different film. Would be nice to compare. Gaumont made a second internegative and positive 35mm of the nitrate from Eye. So, same print, they may have changed the intertitles. On the whole, the early Feuillade films on Antiquity are very innovative in their restrained acting (in drama), the experiments in deep staging (door and curtain openings, voyeurism, repoussoirs), subtle colouring and fine costumes. See also Le fils de Locuste and Aux lions, les chrétiens.

Maria: so maybe we could save this for Eye and compare the two versions there.

Ivo: The ending reminds of the Caligula film with Napierkowska, in which the emperor is also thrown in the river, if I recall right. NB Cassius Dio remarks Heliogabalus was first killed, decapitated and dragged through town, and only afterward his body was thrown into the Tiber. Heliogabalus's second marriage was indeed to a Vestal virgin called Julia Acquilia Severa, causing a huge scandal.

Ivo: Aylin, can you activate the added names of the actors?

For info on the film, see Eric le Roy's Filmographie of Le Film d'Art in the journal 1895: https://journals.openedition.org/1895/4086.

Ivo (on viewing): I already communicated to Bryony in 2016 this might be an Eclair film version of Heliogabale, as the main actress is definitely Olga Demidoff, who was a regular of Eclair and very recognizable because of her length, her long face and pronounced nose. NB The main actor playing Heliogabalus looks a bit  like Jean Hervé, who also played in Héliogabale on stage in 1910, even if Heliogabalus himself was played by another actor. See my card https://www.flickr.com/photos/truusbobjantoo/49328183646. In short, I have doubts whether the BFI film is the Film d'Art version, as the actors mentioned by Le Roy I do not recognize in this film print: Emile Dehelly / Rolla Norman / Henri Desfontaines. Or these three actors may not have played in the Film d'Art version.

 

 

Ivo: Under the title 'Vitellius', IMDb lists a synopsis which combines the two films Heliogabale and Vitellius, both Film d'Art 1910, different actors and directors. Moreover, the names of the main characters in the IMDb synopsis have been switched, as it was Vitellius who symbolised gluttony and it was Heliogabale who was thrown into the Tiber. The part of the IMDb synopsis dealing with the life of emperor Vitellius (=Heliogabalus) perfectly matches the plot of the BFI print. CNC has the film La mort de Vitellius digitally at the BnF, which I will research. 

Ivo: Morgane Spinec (BnF Richelieu) has helped us with pointing at an ad in the journal Ciné-Journal, in which the names of the leading actors are given. Ciné-Journal, 9 April 1910 - https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bd6t5372950b/f19.item. My earlier identification of Olga Demidoff as the abducted Vestal Virgin was right, while Comédie-Française actor Jacques Guilhène [misspelled as Guilhème in Ciné-Journal] played Heliogabalus. Indeed, a caricature of Guilhène on Gallica shows great resemblance with the actor in the film. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b53104282t.r=Jacques%20Guilhene?rk=21459;2. He looks a bit like Hervé, indeed. Finally, with the proof of Ciné-Journal, we can conclude this is the Film d'Art 1910 version and no Eclair nor Gaumont, plus that Le Roy's filmography lacks to mention the main actors. NB BnF lacks a scenario of the film.

fields.title: Jone o Gli ultimi giorni di Pompei (Original) 309731
fields.alt_titles: Gli ultimi giorni di Pompei (Alternative), The Last Days of Pompeii (Alternative), The Priest of Isis (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: Set in Pompeii and featuring the eruption of AD79. Based on the novel by Edward Bulwer-Lytton. Rl.1. Ione and Glaucus, who are in love, buy flowers from a blind girl, Nydia. Arbases, the Egyptian Priest of Isis, holds a magnificent banquet (139). Scenes showing a day in the life of a lady of fashion (186), followed by a chariot race (331). At the races, Arbaces conceives a passion for Ione. He tells her Glaucus is unworthy of her love and that he is infatuated with a blind slave that he bought from Burbius. To prove his love, Glaucus presents Ione with the slave- Nydia, the blind flower seller. Nydia secretly loves Glaucus and tells Ione that he was her saviour. She accompanies Ione to the house of Arbaces (856). Rl.1b. Arbaces instructs his servants to take Nydia to their quarters and conducts Ione into an inner temple. Nydia goes in search of her mistress and, unable to find her, seeks the assistance of Glaucus. In the precincts of the temple and the presence of the dancing girls, Arbaces attempts to violate Ione, who is rescued in time by Glaucus and Nydia (347). Rl.2. Glaucus thanks Nydia for her assistance. She confesses her unhappiness to Julia, a patrician friend, who asks Arbaces for a philtre that will bring Nydia Glaucus' love. Arbaces consults with a witch who then gives Julia and Nydia the philtre. Nydia, believing that she has a love potion, administers it to Glaucus. Glaucus, the victim of Arbaces' jealousy, immediately suffers a fit of madness and dashes wildly through the streets. In the groves of Isis Arbaces and another priest, Menegates, are walking. Glaucus stumbles into the grove and collapses. Menegates goes to his assistance but is killed by Arbaces with Glaucus' sword. However, the murder is witnessed by an elderly priest, Calenus. Glaucus is arrested for the murder while Arbaces offers Calenus untold wealth for his silence. Nydia, learning of Glaucus' arrest, goes to see Arbaces who orders his servants to imprison her. She escapes and wanders blindly in the subterranean passages of Arbaces' house where she overhears Arbaces receive Calenus and conduct him to an inner chamber (1073). Rl.3. Arbaces shows Calenus his treasures, then creeps stealthily from the chamber and locks the old man in. Nydia is recaptured by the servants. Publicly accused by Arbaces, Glaucus is condemned to the arena. Sallust, his friend, is grief-stricken. Ione goes to Arbaces for assistance. She repulses his further advances and is imprisoned. Nydia writes to Sallust for help and when the message is delivered he collects his friends to stage a rescue. The spectacle in the arena commences, watched by Arbaces (3092). Sallust and his friends rescue Nydia and Ione (910). Rl.4. Arbaces continues to watch the sports in the arena, which include fights between gladiators (3352). In the background, Vesuvius begins to belch smoke. Glaucus, alone in the arena, is surrounded by lions but they ignore him. Sallust confronts Arbaces with his victims and denounces him to the crowd who demand that he be thrown to the lions. Vesuvius erupts and the crowds panic. The destruction of Pompeii commences (3571). Guided by Nydia, the reunited lovers take refuge on a ship. Having saved them, the lovesick Nydia quietly slips into the sea (700). (3886ft) Note: The main title is a replacement on 1928 stock. All titles are in English and introductory titles on reels 3 and 4 read "The Priest of Isis" on 1916 stock. The whole film is riddled with periodic gaps, particularly in the last reel. (Shortlist)

JONE OVVERO GLI ULTIMI GIORNI DI POMPEI

Museo Nazionale del Cinema - Fondazione Maria Adriana Prolo (Turin) [ITTM]
fields.comments:
Michael Williams: 

The clip from the 1913 The Last Days of Pompeii made me think about a couple of things. As with other clips, the choices made about what to ‘colour’ from the past is really interesting. I think there was a frieze or two (one outdoors) of figures that were depicted as white, and therefore unpainted – was that ‘authentic’ to the original, or to audience perceptions? I think there was something similar in the background of the set of the House of the Tragic Poet. This aspect of whiteness is something that connects to a number of the films in terms of the representation of race. There was a black slave in this clip – I think he brings something onto set and then walks off. A few other films often featured a trope where two black, muscular, male slaves walk on – sometimes in procession or to bear objects, or as guards. They seem often to then become part of the set, framing a doorway in symmetrical fashion, for example, or observing something going on. Largely they seem to signify the slave (as was noted in discussion) and are largely passive or submissive figures. Do we know who these actors / background artists were, and how they were recruited for the films the project is examining? Getting employment, and some aspect of visibility, could be seen as a ‘positive’ within the context, but are there ways that through performance, and getting noticed, they may be doing more than the part in the script might have anticipated, or can such roles never escape the stereotype? (I know there is some work on the American context in this respect.) How do the representations link to depictions in painting or theatre, as well as to our understanding of antiquity itself? It sounds as if this is a subject for the next workshop. (Perhaps to put alongside other aspects of representation in terms of gender and sexuality..)

AYLIN: 

Jone  Gli Ultimi Giorni di Pompei, was released by Pasquali Film, directed by Giovanni Enrico Vidali, and had a runtime of 95 minutes. As noted by (Stähli,2012), this production, like the first version produced by the Ambrosio Company in 1908, was shot on three-dimensional sets:

"The Rodolfo and Vidali films were both shot on three-dimensional sets that carefully reconstructed Pompeian architecture, streets, house interiors, and furniture, rather than merely using painted backgrounds. Some exterior scenes of the Vidali version were even shot on authentic locations in Pompeii. Both films stage the destruction of Pompeii as a spectacular climax, with the Vidali film using actual footage from an eruption of Mount Vesuvius." (p. 81)

The film was restored in 2008 by the Museo Nazionale del Cinema in Torino and the Cineteca del Comune di Bologna, in collaboration with the Film Museum, the British Film Institute, and the Deutsche Kinemathek Museum für Film und Fernsehen. The restoration aimed to preserve and promote the silent films produced by Turin companies.

This adaptation adheres closely to the novel's script and is filmed in settings designed using information derived from archaeological sources, resulting in a more accurate representation of the ancient city. Similar to the 1908 version, the film opens with an introduction of the characters. However, in contrast to the earlier version, the characters are positioned against constructed set designs rather than blank backgrounds. A significant deviation from the previous two versions is the addition of a female character, Giulia, the daughter of Diomedes, who is introduced as a friend of Glauco. Several interior scenes are set in Giulia's home, the Villa of Diomedes (Figure 1).

 Plan of Villa of Diomedes, produced by Aylin

The film features three notable outdoor scenes. The first occurs at the beginning, following the introductory storyboards, where Mount Vesuvius is depicted smoking in the background. The framing technique used in this scene is reminiscent of stereograph cards, with a circular border at the top (Figure 2).

As in the previous two films—the 1908 original and the 1913 adaptation—the characters are shown in a street scene near the Forum, which is composed of architectural elements such as monumental columns, stairs, urban furnishings like seating units, greenery, and statues. This composition emphasizes the Forum as a central social and meeting space in Pompeii. The second outdoor scene presents a view from another unnamed street (Figure 3).

In this scene, a stepped terrace serves as a backdrop, where a group of figures watches the events unfold before them, resembling spectators in a film. The careful design of this scene highlights that Pompeii's streets, like the Forum, functioned as social spaces where people gathered, observed, and interacted, serving as showcases for the city’s public life. In the third outdoor scene, the camera captures a semicircular seating unit, placed as urban furniture, in front of the entrance to Arbaces' house, where Arbaces and Jone meet (Figure 4). The exedra, set among plants, trees, and statues, features a relief of a woman with a goat, accompanied by a live goat. The inclusion of live animals in the scene likely reflects the directors' intent to evoke everyday life in ancient Pompeii, aiming for historical authenticity. 

Several interior scenes are set in the houses of Arbaces, Giulia, Jone, and Glauco. The reconstructed sets include the cubiculum in Glauco’s house, inspired by the spatial layout of the House of the Tragic Poet, and the peristyle in Jone’s house. Unlike the earlier film versions, the first interior scene occurs in the house of the priest Arbaces, depicting a feast in a flamboyant domestic setting (Figure 5).

Domestic activities performed in reclining positions, such as resting and dining, were popular themes in representations of daily life in ancient Pompeii and are often portrayed with a large number of actors. The tradition of dining in a reclining position, which originated in ancient Greece, continued into the Roman period, evolving to include women and becoming a marker of elite status. The banqueting scene in the film effectively captures the elite nature of this practice and is reminiscent of similar scenes depicted in 19th-century artworks (Figure 6).

Herod’s Birthday Feast displaying a Roman feast scene, Edward Armitage, 1868

The scene is tinted in dark yellow and features reconstructed elements such as monumental circular columns, curtains hung between columns, couches for reclining, small domestic utensils, vases, carpets, and statues. The presence of slaves serving the guests further enhances the scene’s realism. Together, these elements create a vivid, rich, and colorful atmosphere, much like those illustrated in historical paintings.

A second vividly depicted feast in the film takes place in the triclinium of Giulia's house. The scene features Glauco and Giulia in the foreground, with a two-story colonnaded garden in the background, reflecting archaeological evidence that many triclinia were connected to peristyle gardens (Figure 7). Despite variations in specific details, both feasting scenes illustrate one of the most celebrated aspects of Roman upper-class life: the luxurious, conspicuous, and joyful consumption of food and drink. 

The second interior scene sequence depicts Glauco's house, focusing on the moment when Glauco enslaves the blind girl, Nydia, and brings her to his home. The events unfold in the atrium, which is reconstructed as a modified version of the House of the Tragic Poet (Figure 8). Notably, the impluvium in this reconstruction is circular and lacks the corresponding roof opening, the compluvium, unlike the original house, which features a rectangular impluvium and a compluvium. The arrangement of furniture and accessories in the atrium—including a herm, statue, cline table, curtains, and various marble pieces—closely resembles the settings depicted in 19th-century paintings. However, this arrangement is somewhat inaccurate, as herms were typically placed outdoors rather than indoors, according to surviving examples. Furthermore, the rectangular patterned wall paintings are not representative of the actual wall paintings found in the House of the Tragic Poet. It is also noteworthy that, despite differences in the content of various scenes throughout the film, the same objects are repeatedly used as furniture. 

Atrium set design

The third domestic interior scene portrays Jone’s bed-chamber, or cubiculum, which appears to be a reconstruction modeled after Giulia’s bed-chamber in the Villa of Diomedes (Figure 9). Giulia, the daughter of the wealthy Diomedes, had a cubiculum with a view of the villa’s garden. It was a dark space designed for sleep, as vividly described by Bulwer-Lytton, who provided detailed accounts of the room’s furnishings. His descriptions include small-scale items on the dressing table, such as a circular steel mirror, cosmetics, unguents, perfumes, paints, jewelry, combs, ribbons, and gold pins. Bulwer-Lytton (1834) also notes that Giulia's dressing room was located just outside the cubiculum, writing, “before the door, which communicated with the cubiculum, hung a curtain richly broidered with gold flowers.” He further describes the luxurious materials, like the polished steel mirror and gold flowers, highlighting the Roman elite's love of luxury in domestic spaces.

 bed chamber of Jone

In the film, the scene features a seated noblewoman holding a mirror, accompanied by her slave, a composition that replicates well-known 19th-century paintings (Figure 10). Additional details in the scene emphasize the cubiculum’s opulent decoration, including marble furniture, a statue, a small table, and personal items like boxes of various sizes displayed on the table. The background features a painted décor with large-scale female figures, imitating the wall paintings from the Villa of Mysteries, an urban villa near Pompeii’s Herculaneum Gate, which was excavated only four years before the film’s production. The female figures on both the villa's walls and the cubiculum scene also bear a strong resemblance to the dancing women depicted on mid-4th-century BC Attic red-figure vases (Figure 11).

 

Painting displaying a mistress and her slave, In the Roman Palace, Ettore Forti, before 1897

Dancing scene on an Attic red-figure vase of mid 4th century BC

The film, like its previous versions, enables spectators to become pseudo-time travelers to Pompeii before the eruption of Vesuvius, inviting them to reflect on the city's fate. The concept of resurrecting Pompeii's life is echoed in both the scenes and settings, as they choreograph life before and after the eruption, offering a glimpse of the city's afterlife. A mise-en-scène analysis reveals significant effort to imitate Pompeii's buildings, as well as its architectural and urban features, in the set designs. Themes such as banqueting, for instance, share common characteristics with their depiction in 19th-century artworks. Both the film and these paintings exhibit notable scenographic likenesses in their portrayal of domestic architecture, furnishings, costumes, and daily life. For example, the banqueting scenes, from the poses, costumes, and dramatic gestures of the actors to the spatial decorations, as well as the depiction of both slaves and masters, closely resemble those illustrated in 19th-century paintings.

The silent films, particularly this second 1913 version, adopted visual codes from artworks that focused on Pompeii in the 19th century. Compared to earlier versions, this film displays more varied color schemes in the tinted frames, using dark green for interior scenes and purple for outdoor scenes. Like its predecessors, the film employs the “tableau” or “proscenium arch shot,” which captures the actors’ full bodies along with the surrounding space, allowing viewers to perceive depth in the sets. The film carefully selects key locations—such as the atrium, cubiculum, and triclinium in private spaces, and streets, the Forum, the Temple of Isis, and the Amphitheater in public spaces—to convey Pompeii's architectural diversity. The arrangement of furniture in relation to the actions within each scene, such as the combination of chairs, tables, and personal accessories in the cubiculum sequences, or seating units in urban scenes, further contributes to the film’s realism. Additionally, painted décor replicating wall paintings, spatial ornamentation featuring sculptures (such as herms and statues), greenery, curtains, fabrics, and minor details help recreate Pompeii's daily life before the eruption.

 

Displays of urban furniture  (exedra) 

The semi-circular seats were usually placed on the streets with tombs, “where the deceased remains are buried, the custom being to use them in memory of the individual on festival days and anniversaries” (Whalley, 2005, p. 258). In Pompeii exedra were found on the Street of Tombs, the Stabian Street, and the street outside Herculaneum Gate as well as in the private peristyle gardens. Since the furniture and accessories used in the films such, as exedra were produced with reference to the items found in the excavations, they gave the audience information about the actual furnishing of the houses and urban spaces. Although exedra was an outdoor seating arrangement it was used as an interior furnishing in the silent films; the directors must have used it to elaborate the spatiality of the scenes, or even to monumentalize an otherwise ordinary private space.

 

Exedra outside the gate of Herculaneum, Pompeiana: The Topography, Edifices, and Ornaments of Pompeii, William Gell, 1824

Exedra, illustrated in Pompeii, Illustrated with Picturesque Views, William Bernard Cooke, 1827

Plate showing the exedrae on the Street of Tombs, Views of Pompeii, William Light and James Duffield Harding, 1828

Exedra illustration (monument of Mamia), Guide to Pompeii (Scafati Guide, 1900, p. 111)

fields.title: Julius Caesar (Original)
fields.synopsis: No credits. Scene opens on the steps of the Capitol where a soothsayer is speaking to the court. Caesar leaves with Marc Antony whilst Cassius is seen plotting with another man. Cut to athletics scene where Marc Antony wins the race and offers the crown three times to Caesar. Caesar leaves the stadium with Marc Antony. Cassius is seen persuading Brutus to join their conspiracy. The conspirators meet in Brutus' garden. His wife is worried. Calpurnia tells Caesar of a dream she has had and tries to persuade him not to go to the Capitol. However, the conspirators arrive and accompany him. The soothsayer has prepared a letter for Caesar telling him to beware Brutus and stay away from Cassius and Casca. He goes to the Capitol but Caesar will not take his message. Caesar is murdered by the mob and Brutus goes out to address the people. The body of Caesar is brought before the people and Marc Antony delivers his speech that turns the people against the conspirators. Cuts to a scene at an army camp. Inside Brutus' tent, he and Cassius argue but they resolve their differences and drink together. Cassius leaves and a harpist attends Brutus but is soon asleep. Brutus then has a vision of Caesar who warns him of his imminent death. Brutus is distraught. The conspirators lead their armies into battle. In defeat, Cassius makes his servant kill him and Brutus falls on his sword. Marc Antony takes the corpse and it is burnt on a pyre (824ft). (Shotlist)

fields.title: Legende de Midas, La (Original) 332003
fields.alt_titles: König Midas Von Phrygien (Alternative),The Legend of King Midas (Alternative), König Midas (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: Classical myth: Midas prefers Pan's music to Apollo's, so Apollo curses him with asses' ears. His barber whispers the secret to a hole in the ground but the growing reeds whisper it to passersby. No main title. Midas strolls in a studio garden. The fur-clad Pan plays his pipes and Midas awards him a palm branch. The young Apollo plays his lyre but Midas again awards the palm to Pan. Apollo curses Midas with asses' ears. At the palace Midas hides his ears with a cap but exposes himself to his shocked barber. The barber spreads the secret to a laughing soldier and to the mistress of the kitchen who whips him. In a studio wood he tells the secret to a hole in the ground but reeds grow from the ground (personified by maidens flapping their hands like ears). Passersby learn the secret from the whispering reeds, whip off Midas's cap and mock him. Alone, he looks at his reflection (695ft). Note: The German intertitles are numbered 1-2 and 4-6. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Maria: At the Gaumont studio at this time, the director Feuillade was experimenting with the creation of artistic films inspired by paintings, theatre and literature. Borrowing from the tales of transformation told by Ovid, and earlier accounts of the myth on which the Roman poet drew, this film finds humour in how king Midas insulted Apollo. Interestingly, the fantastical plot and stencil-coloured visuals of this ‘silent’ film place great emphasis on sound and music. Its magical effects are produced in a spirit of fun. NB. Midas and his donkey ears are frequently chosen as an example of Greek mythology for discussion in primary schools.

Michael W: I think Maria mentioned the marker sign of the studio / filmmaker’s initials being visible in the exterior shot of this (or possible one of the other) films. That does indeed acknowledge the constructedness of the film, but audiences would likely have been familiar with these devices, as with the ‘AB’ logo (American Biograph) inserted into the sets of D.W. Griffith’s films such as The Lonely Villa (1909) that were intended to prevent rival companies from duplicating their films and selling them as their own. The theme of authenticity, what a representation needs to seem authentic to to be accepted by audiences (what their cultural and historical horizon of understanding is – what they will compare a given film to), is an important one.

Pantelis at FG: Feuillade made many antiquity & myth films (both fantastic and naturalistic). Here fixed frame proscenium arch but disrupted by the uncanny / monstruous & absence of diegetic sound when sound is so essential to the story (a musical competition & whispering). Challenge of sound in plotline. What is relation to theatre & minme? Pathe did a travelogue In the Land of King Midas (Crete) 1920. also there is a children's version by Disney in 1935 (goldent touch). Is this the only surviving print?

The Judgement of Midas, Abraham Janssens (1575-1632)

Ivo: According to FIAF, BFI's print may be unique.

 

Aylin: Nature (whispering reeds) and the Supernatural,  Midas Monument (also known as the Yazılıkaya Midas Monument) in central Turkey one of the most important archaeological remains of the Phrygian civilization, it's commonly associated with Midas due to the inscription mentioning him-Myths and their traces in real life and adaptations), Myths and their associated real life locations should  a possible opic to work on

fields.title: Martire Pompeiana (Original) 333451
fields.alt_titles: Märtyren Von Pompei (Alternative), Pompeian Martyr (Alternative), La Martyre de Pompéi (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: A woman helps her friend to escape from prison and as a result is crucified. No titles. Scene at a Roman feast. A soothsayer arrives and reads bad omens in the hand of the woman present. She is not believed and is led away by one of the servants as the celebrations continue (44). Inside a house, a woman confides in her friend who had just had her fortune told by the soothsayer. The servant arrives and leads the friend away. The woman's husband, a soldier, arrives and recounts his recent exploits (157). The couple in the gardens where the husband leaves in a row boat. The servant arrives leading the king and entourage whilst the wife goes off in the opposite direction. The king presides over a feast at which the servant presents various women to him. The king offers the wife a pearl necklace which she rejects, throwing it to the floor. The king orders her to be beaten and locked away in prison (283). The woman in her bare cell where the servant smuggles her friends in to visit her. The woman asks her friend to take a message to her husband. The friend rides through woodland to deliver it. At the army camp, a wrestling match is in progress. It is followed by a match between the husband and another man using short swords. The friend arrives and tells of his wife's imprisonment and the soldier returns with her (474). Outside the cell, the husband attacks the guard and rescues his wife (519). All three run through the woodlands where the couple take leave of their friend who is subsequently found by the king's servant and is taken prisoner. The friend hanging on a cross in the woods. The escaped couple walk by, take down her body and carry it away. They bury the body in a glade and as they are doing so, a group of friends arrives and leaves flowers by the grave. The king too arrives and, seeing his escaped prisoner, orders his soldiers to arrest her but her husband intervenes and in the ensuing struggle, stabs the king (743). The husband and wife are seen some time later walking past the grave where they find that flowers have taken root and are blooming (749ft). (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Maria: this looks interesting to me. because in fact secular. woman is martyred for sake of a female friend. about class and gender, sexual violence. not clear why called Pompeiana. dir Giuseppe de Liguoro. has no intertitles.

Maria:  it provides a secular not a religious martyrdom, sets it in Pompeii not Rome, and focuses on selfless devotion between female friends who are courtesans under the control of a pimp. Ivo Blom has connected the film’s opening feast in honour of Venus to frescoes of banqueting in a Pompeian house. And observed how a tripod in a scene between the two courtesans links back to ones found in Pompeii. These visual and material connections with Pompeii could be pursued in terms of how the excavation of erotic objects and images at Pompeii developed for the site a disturbingly erotic charge. It is interesting to note that the excavation of the Villa of Mysteries was taking place in the same year as the film’s release. Note that in the film, some of the characters are dressed up to look satyr-like as in the frescoes. Ivo has also noted the unusual feature of this films ending. Iconographic works showing female crucifixion was a rarity, even for female saints. But the Pompeian Martyr shows a prostitute sacrificing herself for her friend, being crucified and then taken down from the cross with the tenderness one might expect to be shown to Christ. Flowers then grow miraculouslyon her grave. The challenge this film presents to the more conventional accounts of Christian martyrdom and its Pompeian setting certainly deserve further attention.

FG: Compare the narrative to Roman drama on the Italian stage at the time (because seems Plautine or Terentian, in terms of focus on prostitutes & their lovers, stock characters). PM says there was a strong interest in bringing back Roman drama to the stage in this period. Also commedia d'arte for comic elements (like the pimp / clown, a kind of master of ceremonies). Christie: Also unusual to see a martyr being taken down and buried, cf medieval mystery plays of Christian martyrdom where martyrs and angels can't vanish because it is a physical performance, an actual person.Suggests communities with hierarchies of different kinds (the courtesans & their pimp, the gladiators stopped by their master). see community of women around the grave at the end. Christie: Gladiators wrestling - like scenes from a circus show. Odd pause to show it and the sword fight.

fresco w banquet scene, House of the Chaste Lovers, Pompeii

villa of mysteries (note satyr)

Christian Martyr on the Cross/ St Julia, also called Crucified Martyress (Gabriel von Max 1866, coll. unknown)

fields.title: Martyre, Le (Original) 143376
fields.synopsis: Historical, religious. The son of a Prefect in Rome is condemned to death for being a Christian. No main title. The household try to entertain the Prefect's son, Albanus. The Prefect arrives and brings with him a dancing dwarf, lady and bear but these fail to stir Albanus from his reverie. Albanus is in love with the slave Fabiola. He meets her by the river. She informs him that she is a Christian, showing him the Christian sign on the side of a statue, and will not listen to Albanus until he too is a Christian. Fabiola visits the potter Lycius (Lucius) who is also enamoured of her. However, Fabiola dismisses his advances. In revenge, Lycius follows her to the Christian meeting place where Albanus is being baptised. Lycius informs the Prefect of the meeting. A body of guards is dispatched to the meeting and the Christians arrested. The Christians are brought to trial before the Prefect. His son reveals his identity but is condemned to death. The next day the Prefect goes to collect his son's body. The doors to the arena are thrown open to reveal the crucified body of his son. By the banks of the river two men observe the body of Fabiola floating down the river (621ft). Note: Intertitles in German. (Shotlist)

fields.title: Martyrs, Les (Original) 22993
fields.synopsis: Christian martyrs in the Roman arena. A lion trainer rounds up one of his animals, which is obedient to his orders, and rolls over to be stroked. Attendants clearing the debris of a chariot crash, raking the track, and removing the body of the driver. A procession of trumpeters and soldiers escort in two senators, followed by two Christians. The Christians kneel to salute the royal box, then suffer themselves to be bound to the cross- trees. Lions enter the arena, and tear at the victims. The lions are ushered out with dripping hunks of flesh in their jaws (150ft). (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Maria: conventions of melodrama. possibly replicating painting. 

Ivo: Might well indeed, cf. JL David, FX Fabre, JFJ de St Quentin, JB Alizard, P. Peyron, Delacroix, L.J. Lebrun, Gerome, Siemiradzki, Feuerbach.

Ivo: La morte di Socrate (1909): in addition to the actors already indicated with Bernardini's Il cinema muto italiano: Giuseppe Gambardella as the fat judge, the skinny Lorenzo Soderini and the famous Amleto Novelli (the hero from Quo vadis?) as two acolytes of Socrates, I recognize Maria Caserini as Socrates' wife. She played in various Cines films and afterward acted as Agrippina in the Gloria production Nerone e Agrippina by her husband Mario Caserini. Although the director of La morte di Socrate is unknown, I would not be surprised if Mario Caserini, Maria's husband, was the director. Difficult to say who played Socrates with the false beard, wig and fake nose. Interesting that Socrates covers his head before falling down, similar to Julius Caesar when being murdered. Was this a theatrical tradition, I ask myself? lso, weird that afterward he rises again and writes his last words. While the dungeon scene is understandably rather generic, the previous scene with the judges outside has the typical klismos chairs, this time decorated as on Tadema's paintings (in the Roman' Antiquity films there is no decoration, but the form is the same). It is a strange film with only two sets and the second scene is basically only about grieving, first by the family, then by the acolytes. Novelli is very present in his performance, more than others.

fields.comments:
Ma: Dir. William K. L. Dickson, Mutoscope & Biography Syndicate, UK.

Framed by the ruined arches of Pompeii (those of Tiberius near & Caligula further back), men and women in costume dance a Neapolitan folk dance, while a woman plays a tammorra (a big tambourine). From the back, a group of performers dressed as soldiers advances and interrupts the dance. The dance then resumes. A number of spectators are visible as well as the director of the performance, in suit and hat.

silent cinema spreading worldwide topographical myths promoting Naples. stereotypes of Naples and its environs already visible in paintings, photographs and engravings, the dance appears as well as 19th c ballets and opera. Dancers of the Neapolitan tarantella (a version of Apulian tarantella, but representing courtship) essential part of the southern landscape, in both Italian and British-made films - recurrent elements southern setting, traditional costumes (castanets & handkerchiefs), open space, tambourine or tammorra (bigger), circular movements of dancing couples, steps & movements recalling peasant everyday life (gestures of arms recalling sowing & harvesting). The dance a display to fascinate foreigner visitors. Setting in Forum of Pompeii? - here juxtaposition of ancient & familiar imperial grandeur (the triumphal arches) with exotic folk culture. But also stasis & destruction of the past with movement & life of the present. Image of the Italian picturesque. Also emphases the musicality and movement of cinema. and might have been of nostalgic interest if seen by Italian migrants to other countries.

See Elisa Uffreduzzi, ‘Tarantella dance in early cinema’ (Journal of Nineteenth Century Theatre and Film, 46.2 2019):

 

Aylin: 

Pompeii is featured in the Neapolitan Dance at the Ancient Forum of Pompeii, a two-minute-long film directed by William Kennedy-Laurie Dickson and produced by the British Mutoscope & Biograph Company in 1898. Dickson filmed this footage during a tour of Italian destinations on his way to Rome to film the Pope. The film presents an open-air public performance of a traditional Italian tarantella—a popular subject in the art of the period—set in the Forum, with the Arch of Tiberius in the foreground and the Arch of Caligula visible in the background (Figure 1). 

Images showing the tarantella performance at the Forum of Pompei

The tarantella is a traditional Italian folk dance characterized by a competitive dynamic between the dancer and the drum player, in which each attempts to outpace the other by dancing or playing faster and for a longer duration. The performance is typically accompanied by instruments such as the mandolin, guitar, accordion, and tambourines, contributing to its lively and rhythmic nature. A similar tarantella performance was captured by the pioneering photographer Giorgio Sommer in 1870, renowned for his albumen prints of Pompeii and Vesuvius (Figure 2).

Albumen silver print showing tarantella performers with Vesuvius at the back, Giorgio Sommer, 1870 (Source: https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/305832)

The film begins with dancers dressed in traditional costumes, as noted in its synopsis, and the dance is accompanied by a procession of performers mimicking a troop of soldiers. Although shot from a distance, Mount Vesuvius is visible as a silhouette in the background. By the time the footage was recorded, the Forum had been fully excavated. The scene frames the north side of the Forum, offering views of the Temple of Jupiter and the two honorary arches, with Vesuvius looming majestically in the background, dominating the scene. This view, featuring the temple and arches with Vesuvius behind them, became an iconic perspective often depicted in artwork due to its dramatic composition.

fields.synopsis: The life of Emperor Nero. Based on the dramatic poem by Arrigo Boito. No main title. Nero and his servant talking in the palace. They leave (6). Two men walking along a quiet street at night. As they disappear the servant and Nero appear; the servant holds a cloak around his face. Nero points to something, or someone, unseen and they leave. Nero is going to meet Poppaea (22). Nero leads the Empress Octavia from the temple to the acclaim and adulation of the crowd (87). Nero and Octavia in a garden; she appears to be pleading with him (91). A street in Rome. A maid who has witnessed Octavia's assassination spreads the news of her mistress's murder and shows the veil which is snatched by a man and waved aloft. The crowds follow him (121). Rome is set alight by torch-bearers.; the crowds flee in panic (156). Nero and Poppaea on the tower of the palace, Nero plays a lyre and laughs with Poppaea as they watch Rome burn (167). Gladiators and women feasting and drinking. Nero embracing and kissing Poppaea. Octavia remonstrates with Nero and is pushed roughly away. Nero leaves with Poppaea. Octavia's maid comforts her and leads her away (222ft). Note: Incomplete. The scenes are in the wrong order. The number on the first intertitle frame is 44501. There is nitrate damage on several frames. German intertitles. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
M: Among Italy’s first ‘kolossals’ or historical epics. The plot condenses into one reel the Italian melodramatic tradition for Nero from grand opera to popular tragedy, where the emperor is a ruthless son who kills his mother, a callous husband who rejects his wife and an impassioned pursuer of his mistresses. The actors gesture majestically within pictorial sets. Before Nero’s flight and suicide, an interesting sequence uses the special effect of superimposition to show the terrified Nero a nightmare vision of Christian suffering in the arena for which he will be responsible. The tableau closely recalls the composition of two paintings: (1) The Christian Martyrs' Last Prayer (Jean-Léon Gérôme, 1883) and then (2) Nero's Torches (Henryk Siemiradzki, 1876). According to the American Moving Picture World of 6 November 1909, it possessed ‘such a marvelous realism of affect that as we sat and watched this colored part of the film, we seemed, as it were, to hear the cries of the victims’.

 

    

IB: There was the stage production Nero (1906) with Herbert Beerbohm Tree as Nero. Stephen Phillips’ Nero opened at His Majesty’s Theatre, London, in 1906. In addition to Tree, Constance Collier played Poppaea, while Tree's wife Helen Maud Holt played Agrippina, mother of Nero. Below a postcard in my collection.

IB: Arrigo Boito died in 1918 before being able to finish his opera Nerone, which eventually premiered posthumously at La Scala in Milan on May 1, 1924, Below some images of the sets, issued on postcards in my collection.

 Nerone, Boito, Il Tempio di Simon Mago (Act II)

Nerone, Boito, L'orto cristiano (Act III)

Nerone, Boito, Scena dell'Oppidum (Act IV)

Nerone, Boito, Partial collapse of the ceiling of the Spoliarium (Finale)

fields.title: Odissea, L'  (Original) 246233
fields.alt_titles: L' Odyssée D'homère (Alternative), Die Abenteuer des Odysseus (Alternative), Homer's Odyssey (Alternative), L' Odyssée (Alternative), Abreise des Odysseus (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: The legend of Odyseeus. Rl.1. Main title (20). Odysseus takes leave of his wife Penelope, his son Telemach and his fatehr Laertes. With his family he leaves the palace and is greeted by his subjects. At the beach he goves instructions to his captain and gets ready to board his ship. Believing Odysseus to be dead the local chiefs call on Penelope to choose a new husband, they are seen outside the palace feasting. During the day Penelope weaves a cloak for the now dead Laertes. When the suitors call she says she cannot wed until the cloak is complete. However, at nigt she unravels her day's work. She is observed by a maid who calls the suitors in, they reproach her. The fall of Troy: the citizens run in terror as the Greeks invade; Odysseus rides into the city in his chariot with his men and the city is razed. From his ship Odysseus observes the destruction of Troy by fire. Odysseus and his crew land at the idland of the Cyclops Polyphemus, Odysseus leads a number of his men to fetch water. In a cave they observe the arrival of the Cyclops who closes the door. The Cyclops sees the men and seizes two of tehm, smashing them to the ground. While the Cyclops sleeps, Odysseus organises his men to carry a large log and burning one end they attack and blind the giant. He runs to the door and opens it (580). Rl.2. Odysseus and his crew make their escape from the cave of the Cyclops by hiding under the sheep as the Cyclops let the herd out to graze. All escape to the ship and set sail. As they sail past a headland, the Cyclops hears them and throws a rock, missing them. The Cyclops rages on the shore. In order to sail past the Sirens the crew block each other's ears with wax and bind Odysseus to the mast so he can hear the song but will not be drawn to his death. The ship sails past the dog-headed monster, Scylla where Odysseus loses more of his men. The ship arrives in Sicily. The crew find the holy bull of Zeus and eat it despite Odysseus' protestations. Odysseus pleads forgiveness fromZeus. However, while at sea, Zeus takes his revenge and strikes the ship with a thunder bolt, which sets the ship on fire. Odysseus is then seen walking through a garden with Calypso. Later he begins to build himself a raft. Calypso helps him by bringing rope and an axe, and later a sail. As Odysseus stes sail on his raft Calypso stands and weeps. While at sea, Odysseus sails into a storm created by Neptune, father of the Cyclops. Odysseus is washed up onto the shore of Scheria. Tired and injured he drags himself onto land and falls asleep. A group of maidens arrive on the scene and discover Odysseus. Nausicaa, daughter of Alcinous, King of the Phaeacians, comes to Odysseus' aid and brings him fresh clothes (877). Rl.3. Nausicaa escorts Odysseus to her fatehr's palace. Odyseeus is impressed by the palace and wanders around its grounds. In the throne room Odysseus tells his story. Impressed, the King offers Odysseus riches and a ship to return home. Odysseus is carried from the ship and set on the beach. The Godess Pallas Athene appears to Odysseus and helps disguise him as a beggar. Odysseus takes bread at the home of Eumaeus. Telemach is also there and with the help of Pallas Athene, Odysseus reveals himself as Telemach's father. In his beggar's disguise, Odysseus arrives at his palace to the suitors encamped in the courtyard. He is ill-treated by the suitors. Odysseus is awakened by the suitors' carousing and he watches them go off with maidens into the woods. Odysseus and his son remove the weapons from the courtyard. penelope announces from the palace that she will marry the suitor whocan pull Odysseus' bow. The suitors try and fail, Odysseus still in disguise pulls the bow and fires an arrow. Pallas Athene appears and changes Odysseus into his royal robes, He at once sets upon the suitors killing them all. Penelope and Odysseus are reuinited (1127). (2584ft) Note: The scenes with the Cyclops are created by the superimposition of Odysseus and his crew in one corner of the frame. Note: The Sirens are women standing in water with mermaid tails attatched to their waist giving the impression of swimming. Note: Intertitles are numbered 1-47; 3 and 7 are missing. Note: Main title reads Die Abenteuer des 'Odysseus' nach der Dichtung von Homer Die Odyssee/ Die Abreise des Odysseus. Note: The film was re-released in 1914. References: Aldo Bernardini. Archivio del cinema Italiano: Vol 1 Il cinema muto 1905-1931, p.282. Herbert Birett. Das Filmangebot in Deutschland 1895-1911, no.7022. Herbert Birett. Verzeichnis in Deutschland gelaufner Filme: Filmzenzur 1911-1920, p.673, no.5165. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
AYLIN

This paragraph is taken from The Moving Picture World, 17 February 1912: 584. It serves as a good example for discussing the potential contribution of films to education. Pantelis Michelakis (Michelakis, Wyke, 2013) in Homer in silent cinema also highlights the competition mentioned below.

College Students Compete for "Odyssey" Prize, Monopol Film Company Offers Reward for Best Essay on Great Poem

" To stimulate interest in Homer's "Odyssey," the Monopol Film Company only last December offered a cash prize of $100 for the best thousand-word essay on the greatest of all epic poems. Ten thousand letters were written to school superintendents and principals throughout the United States and Canada. The rules of the competition were simple, yet wide enough in scope to embrace a contest that would reach far and wide. The students of every school, college and university were invited to submit essays, which were to be read and passed upon by a committee under the direction of the Rev. Doctor Stockton.

To date, nearly 1,000 manuscripts have reached the Monopol office. As a publicity getter, this has proven one of the best and most inexpensive stunts devised. The students became enthused over the contest; they in turn worked up an interest with the parents at home, and this occurring in nearly every town in America, the interest in the Odyssey became universal.

The winner's name and photograph will be reproduced in the trade papers and also in the home town of the student. Another feature of unique importance is that the Monopol Film Company has on file at its office letters from every university president in America commending the "Odyssey" as a masterpiece of world's literature."

 

'Lecturing the Pictures' from the same source,  Were there regular lectures on films? who were the lecturers and what were the topics?

fields.title: Parapluie fantastique, La (Original) 22966
fields.alt_titles: Ten Ladies in One Umbrella (Alternative), Dix femmes sous une parapluie (Alternative), Dix femmes sous une ombrelle (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: TRICK. A conjuror evokes women in national dress from an umbrella and then transforms them into an ancient Greek tableau. Library of Congress data (6). Méliès copyright (9). No main title. The set of a side show under construction. A theatre booth 'Galathea Theatre'. A conjuror in top hat and tails and carrying a cane and overcoat enters. He sets down his hat and cane with a floursh and throws the overcoat into the wings. He takes the hat and begins to juggle with it. The hat turns into a ball which he bounces up and down. Taking his cane he balances the ball on it. The ball is transformed into a piece of material. He spins the material on the cane and it becomes an umbrella. He jumps on the stage and waving the umbrella across him he is transformed into a Greek in classical dress. He shakes out of his umbrella a young woman in national dress. Waving his umbrella he evokes five more women in national dress and then shaking flowers from the umbrella he evokes a fairy who stands on the centre of the platform playing a lyre. He conjures up three more women. The women form a tableau in front of the stage. The conjuror turns the stage into a Greek temple. At a sign from the conjuror they jump from the stage and are transformed into contemporary clothes. The women dance. The Greek temple is turned into the original theatre set. The conjuror leaps over a stool and is transformed into his original clothes. He picks up his umbrella, tears off the material and it becomes his overcoat. He looks around, picks up the ball and throws it to the ground. It rebounds and becomes his top hat. He acknowledges the audience and bows (82ft). [16mm]. Note. The 'Star' catalogue describes the national dress of the women conjured up in the following order: Algerian, Swiss, Spaniard, Russian, Turk, Hollander, Swede, Gipsy and Fairy. It is difficult when watching the images to ascribe the costumes accurately. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Maria: [Le Parapluie Fantastique] George Méliès, Star-Film, France c. 3 mins.

At a booth under construction called ‘Galathea Theatre’,  a conjurer performs tricks with his top hat and cane which is transformed into an umbrella. He is transformed into an ancient Greek who shakes a series of women in national dress out of the umbrella and then a fairy who begins to play a lyre. The next three women he conjures up form a tableau at the front of the stage which he turns into a Greek temple. The women are transformed back into their original clothes, the temple into the theatre, and the ancient Greek into the top-hatted conjurer.

Michael Williams: Really great material. I particularly enjoyed Ten Ladies in One Umbrella, which is still technically impressive. The way the tableau vivant was gradually formed was striking, and links strongly to the kind of contemporary crossovers between painting, photography and cinema discussed by Lynda Nead.

Pantelis: ancient Greece not just in film themes, also in film criticism & architectyure. Showed examples of cinemas built in Greek style. Implies cinema a new religion (a temple) with a distinguished ancestry. Relates this film to other productions by Melies concerning ancient Greece, including Juptier's Thunderbolt in same year and this the next in numbering. After that, can see that the women in this film like the Muses (and elsewhere cinema called the tenth Muse). Here classical clothing & classical instruments. backdrop turns into a temple with reference to Galatea & Pygmalion myth. [a founding myth for cinema as animation of the inanimate]. In M, usually women materialise and vanish (objects transformed by M). but here 10 women (like mass production) and doesn't make them disappear. also M transforms objects & transforms self into ancient Greek. P says lots of material about this film in Lib of Congress inc a paper print.

Aylin: BFI collection includes another version of the film from 1907. 

Le PARAPLUIE FANTASTIQUE (Original)

The CHARMED UMBRELLA (Alternative)

Director: Segundo de Chomón
Production Company: Pathé Frères

fields.title: Patrizia e schiava (Original) 58215
fields.alt_titles: Patrizierin und Sklavin (Alternative), Afra (Alternative), Patricia and the Slave (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: An African slave girl kidnaps her mistress's child, who is then abandoned and cared for by mermaids until returned to her mother. A man talks to a woman by a well, and looks despondent when she and her friend refuse his advances and leave (25). Marcella, a Roman matron, is shown skins by a trader. The trader lines up a row of slave girls and Marcella buys Afra, an African princess (122). Afra is instructed to look after Marcella's child (164). Afra and the child on a beach. The slave-master orders her to carry out her duties (179). A boat carrying Marcella is rowed to a pier where she disembarks with her servants (248). She greets her child on the seashore; Afra bows to her but gives her a sullen look (269). A party of Afra's followers arrive and find her on the seashore, scolding the child; she escapes with them and they take the child (368). The slave-master runs after them in vain (431). Marcella is being tended by slaves at her villa when the slave-master brings the news of the escape and kidnapping. From the terrace they watch the marauder's ship leaving, pursued by a boatload of soldier (534). [Section missing: the marauder's boat is wrecked by a storm]. The soldiers return in their boat (592). Marcella pines in her garden (642). Soldiers bring the news to her; she despairs until a friend tells her to ask the gods (713). Marcella leaves gifts at the statue of the Goddess of the Sea - the statue points to an inset showing the child playing with mermaids on some rocks (844). Marcella arrives by litter at the entrance to the mermaids' home and enters a cave (882). In a subterranean passage, she hears the child's voice. She emerges onto the seashore, where the mermaids give her back her child (928). She returns with the child back up the cliffs and through the cave (956). She reaches her litter, where people throw flowers and acclaim her (985ft). Note: The title used in Britain is a mistranslation. A literal translation is `Patrician and slave'. There is second viewing copy (Joye: Rome N24, 988ft) with no title, German intertitles and without the shots of mermaids. (Shotlist)

Already digitized for live performance 2009 UCL [better copy elsewhere?]

Ivo: Gemona has preserved a complete, tinted print in colour. I have scan of it. Bologna preserved a fragment, Madrid has also material. The film is of 1909, not 1919. It is a very interesting, early Cines film, director unknown. It is almost the oldest Cines film with a Roman theme, apart from La rivale (1908, Bologna). Many of the 'Roman' props (chairs, stools, tables, lamps, curtains, litter, etc.) in this film have been used for some 15 years at Cines and its follow-ups (see my book). Interesting visions at the temple, backlight shots in the cave, and theme of slavery (North Africans, even royalty, enslaved to Romans), history and mythology mixed.

fields.title: Principessa e Schiava (Original) 3366
fields.alt_titles: Rückkehr des Siegers (Alternative), Princess and Slave (Alternative), Princesse et Esclave (Alternative), Prinzessin und Sklavin (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: Ancient Rome. Roman princess is jealous of general's love for captured slave girl. Roman general Vitellius returns after conquering the Dacians, leading, in front of the Imperial lodge, a triumphal march with the captured Dacians as slaves. He is passionately admired by the Roman Imperial princess Fausta, who observes him jealously as he meets with Aida, a slave girl with whom he is in love. Fausta summons Vitellius to her room and declares her love, which he rejects. Discovering the loving couple in a garden, she swears revenge. She denounces them both to Caesar, who forces the Senate to have both the general and the slave girl thrown into the cells. Vitellius chisels through the wall of his cell and pulls his beloved through to join him. Wrapped in a cloak, Fausta visits his cell to declare her love once more. They overpower her and escape, the slave girl wrapped in the princess' cloak. They reach a ferry boat and cast off from the banks of the river. Fausta is discovered, tied up in the cells. She leads the Roman guard in pursuit, but they arrive at the river to find the lovers already in midstream (809ft). Note: Possibly incomplete. Original length 919ft. Archive copy 809ft. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Ivo: Principessa e schiava (Itala Film 1909), which I have seen at the BFI. The film has a totally different plot and actors from Patricia e schiava. In Bernardini's Il cinema muto italiano vol. 1905-1909, they partly mix up, as one of the two photos placed with Principessa e schiava actually is from Patrizia e schiava. Bernardini also identifies wrong actors and lacks names. The main actor is indeed Vardannes (who was also a famous comic as Toto' and Fringuelli), while the princess is played by Adriana Costamagna. Both also act in Giulio Cesare (Itala, also 1909).  

Ivo: the bench used in this film, which was also used in Giulio Cesare, reminds of the exedra benches painted by Lawrence Alma Tadema.
