fields.title: Quo Vadis? (Original) 42268
fields.synopsis: HISTORICAL DRAMA. A story of the persecution of the Christians by the Emperor Nero. Rl.1. [Section missing] Petronius persuades Nero to have the beautiful Lygia, a girl taken hostage by the Romans, taken away from the house of Aulus Plautus, her Christian guardian. Lygia is escorted from the house by Nero's guard, after a tearful farewell to Aulus and his family. She is followed by her devoted Slave Ursus, who has sworn to protect her. Aulus suspects that Vinicius, a young general in love with Lygia, is behind the abduction but he protests his innocence and confronts his uncle, Petronius, with the accusation. Petronius tells his nephew that Nero will give Lygia to Vinicius as a slave. Pleased with this scheme Vinicius bids Aulus accept Nero's will. At a feast given by nero, Vinicius pays court to Lygia. [Section missing.] Lygia dismisses Ursus and strolls with Actea in the gardens of Nero's palace where they encounter Nero's wife Poppea. Lygia begs her to intercede with Nero to have her returned to Aulus, but Poppaea decides to have her handed over to Vinicius. However, the guards taking her to Vinicius' house are overpowered by a group led by Ursus, and she is rescued. Vinicius, troubled by her disappearance, angrily rejects Petronius' offer of his own slave, Eunice. Eunice is devoted to Petronius and begs to remain in his service, even after he orders her to be flogged. A charlatan soothsayer, Chilon Chilonides, visits Vinicius and offers to find Lygia in return for money. Meanwhile Nero, upset at the death of his child, which he attributes to the influence of Lygia, blames Petronius for having brought her into his household. Petronius regains Nero's favour through flattery. Chilon reports to Vinicius that he has discovered Ursus working at a miller's house. Chilon learns from Ursus that the Apostle Peter will be preaching to his Christian followers that night. Knowing that Kygia will be there, Vinicius plans to abduct her with the aid of a strong henchman, Croton. In disguise Chilon, Vinicius and Croton follow the crowd and listen to the Apostle's speech (1897). Rl.2. Afterwards they follow Lygia back to the house where the Christians are hiding her, but their attempt to abduct her is foiled by Ursus, who kills Croton and overpowers Vinicius. At Lygia's bidding he spares the Roman's life. Vinicius recovers consciousness in the Christian's household. Influenced by the Apostle's sermon and realising that Lygia has saved his life, he feels growing sympathy for the Christian cause. Summoning Chilon, he lets it be known that the Christians have saved him from Croton, and Chilon is thrown out. Lygia modestly rejects Vinicius' declaration of his love, but later she confesses to a horrified Aulus that she is in love with the Roman. The Apostle Peter, however, rules that Christians should respect married love. Vinicius meanwhile has returned to Petronius, determined to continue his pursuit of Lygia. Chilon reveals that he knows Lygia's new hiding place. Vinicius has Chilon flogged, then forces him to lead him there. Chilon swears vengeance. Vinicius promises the Christians he will adopt their faith if they allow him to marry Lygia. The Apostle Peter brings Lygia forth and blesses their love. At another feast, called to celebrate his voyage to Antium, Nero seeks inspiration for his epic poem. With one of his guards, Tigellinus, he devises the plan of setting fire to Rome. Tigellinus leaves to carry out the plan. At the feast Vinicius tells Nero of his love for Lygia. Meanwhile the citizens of Rome flee in panic from the burning buildings. Vinicius returns to search for Lygia in the flames, but is overcome and has to be rescued. Nero arrives to witness the burning and plays his lyre while watching the destruction from his balcony. An angry crowd gathers, forcing Nero to retreat inside his palace. Petronius is obliged to placate them with promises of food and new public works. Vinicius goes with Chilon to the catacombs, where they find the Apostle Peter preaching to his followers. Vinicius asks to be baptised and is joyfully reunited with Lygia. Some days later the mob, angry at the lack of food, call for a sacrifice. Poppaea suggests that Nero should make the Christians a scapegoat to propitiate the crowd's fury (1928). Rl.3. Chilon denounces the Christians, including Glaucos, Ursus, Lygia and Vinicius. All but Vinicius are arrested. Petronius tells him to rescue Lygia and escape with her but he finds the prison well guarded. As he walks dejectedly back, he is mocked by Chilon, who has been elevated to the nobility. The day og the games arrives, when the Christians are to be sacrificed. Petronius, in disfavour with Nero, arrives to watch the spectacle and is capriciously greeted by the Emperor. Vinicius searches unsuccessfully for Lygia among the prisoners. A chariot race begins, and Nero salutes the victor. The crowd acclaims the entry of the gladiators. Nero turns down a plea from a defeated gladiator. Chilon overhears Vinicius tell Petronius of his failure to find Lygia. Meanwhile the Christians are dragged into the arena and fed to the lions. Chilon collapses when he witnesses the scene. A bull enters the arena with Lygia strapped to its back. Ursus overcomes the beast and releases her, to the joy of Vinicius. The crowd demands their release. Some days later Petronius, in disgrace with Nero, takes his own life by slitting his wrists. His devoted slave Eunice dies with him. Chilon witnesses the bodies of the Christian martyrs he has denounced and accuses Nero of burning Rome. Nero's supporters pursue him into a garden where he has time to be baptised by Paul of Tarsus before being led away for punishment by the soldiers. Next day, as the Apostle Peter and Nazaire leave Rome on the Appian Way, Peter sees a vision of Christ and realises his duty to return to Rome. Nero's soldiers revolt and proclaim Galba as Emperor. Nero, forced to flee, is killed by freed slaves after refusing the chance to take his own life. Soldiers arrive and cover the body. An epilogue shows Christ breaking the chains of several worshippers at his feet (1791). (5616ft) (Shotlist)

fields.comments: Michael Williams: I really enjoyed seeing A Roman Scandal and Bending Hur, which opens up the parodic representations of antiquity, as well as animated films, both of which seem very fruitful areas to explore. The area of copying, pastiche and parody seems rich with classicism, and all the copies that proliferated in antiquity too. The statue-play was interesting, and taps into that wider field of the tableau vivant or pose plastique already mentioned (and by Maria on the day), it was connected to race here, too. Lots of knowingness about the ancient past as framed by cinema.

fields.title: Roman Britain (Original) 18600
fields.synopsis: INSTRUCTIONAL: A reconstruction of life in Britain in Roman times. R.1. A British village in AD49 of mud huts with thatched roofs (36-46); when danger threatens people rush in and shut the gates in the palings (56-73); the British getting the harvest in (85-102); a Briton hunting a rabbit with a spear (108-143); a Briton basket making (151-168); pottery making (171-209); a Chieftain's house (218-240); a woman spinning (245-290); a harpist in the Chieftain's house (295-304); the Queen crowns herself on the death of the King (318-351); she un-plaits her hair as a sign of mourning (357-396); a girl puts flowers under a tree for spirits she worships (403-432); people listening to a Druid priest (439-464); stone altar of the druids (471-534); the ceremony includes singing and dancing (540-558). R.2. Part 2. Roman civilian life. Roman soldiers marching through the country (40-62); a gathering in a Roman town (113); Roman soldiers marching (121-135); soldiers in a town (145-153); the Temple of Victory in the town (156-182); a Roman dandy and his followers (190-217); Roman soldiers act as police and prevent disturbance in Forum (223-235); Roman women gossiping (241-257); British slaves with loads (264-271); Governor in the Basilica (284-299); he receives orders from the Emperor (303-378); he is massaged and toileted (387-416); the guests assemble for supper (420-431); the supper (438-474) (479-489); the sentries leave the bridge (493-511); slaves raise the bridge (519-535); signalling at night from the towers with torches (592-562); guards keeping watch at night (569-574) (579) R.3. Romans and Britain at war. The standard of Rome (46-52); a Roman general reviews his army (55-90); the Roman army on the march (93-134); Roman soldiers carrying kit on sticks (141-159); they halt to rest (163-174); the short step of the soldiers, one falls and is left (188-205); the army camp at night (215-242); Roman soldiers in conflict with Britons in their village (252-323); the British plan revolt (328-362); the revolt spreads (378-386); the British knife-wheeled chariot (393-430); British women and children cheering their warrior's on (438-537); British began battles with display of chariots and cavalry to frighten the enemy (499-643); Roman wall of shields (651-659); British are repulsed (665-671); Roman advance in wedge formation (677-683); the British are routed (688-702); roman standard (705-712) The End (723) (Shotlist)

fields.title: Santa Cecilia (Original) 24913
fields.synopsis: The story of the Christian martyr Saint Cecilia. Unknown to her parents, Cecilia, a Roman patrician, has become a Christian. She has two suitors for her hand, Valerianus and Lentulus. Cecilia promises to marry Valerianus if he converts to Christianity. Later, Lentulus sees Valerianus enter the catacombs to be baptised by Bishop Urbanus and denounceshim to the Prefect, who orders his arrest. Cecilia and Valerianus are married according to Roman law, but during the nuptial banquet, Valerianus is torn from his wife and dragged before the Senate. Here he proudly affirms that he is a Christian and is sentanced to death. Cecilia claims the body of her husband and it is reverently laid to rest in the catacombs. As she leaves the catacombs she is arrested on suspicion of being a Christian and, refusing to pay homage to the gods, suffers martyrdom (917ft). Note: English intertitles. Main title missing. Reference: Maria Adriana Prolo, Storia del cinema italiano (Milan, 1951), p.141. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Ivo: Indeed an interesting topic (at the time very popular in lantern slide series, postcard series, stage versions etc.). This film version is by Enrique Santos who together with Guazzoni and Caserini was responsible for various Antiquity films at Cines in the early 1910s, in the era of the shorts. Return of the same Roman furniture from Cines (mensa delphica table, cathedra chairs, Minerva Giustiniani statue, curtains with diagonal motif, Nike statue, murals similar to Fourth Style Pompei murals e.g. House of the Vettii, etc.). Identical set in Virginia (Cines, 1911) and almost identical set in opening shot of Agrippina (Guazzoni, 1911). Set design retakes elements from La rivale (Cines, 1908, print Bologna) like the frieze with sphynxes, and from Patrizia e schiava (Cines, 1909, print Gemona/BFI) like the mensa delphica.

Maria: re martyrdom (why so popular as a theme? how do the films draw on rich traditions for representing early Christianity? how do the films distinguish between lived environment of Romans v that of Christians? how do Italian martrydoms differ from French or American? agency of women?) this an adaptation to screen of the life of a venerated virgin martyr. She was an important saint for Romans: the Church of Santa Cecilia in Trastevere is supposed to sit over the house in which she once lived. She is served not just by a Church but also by a rich visual and written tradition, including in modern times lantern slides, postcards and stage plays that commemorate her martyrdom under the emperor Alexander Severus in c 230 AD. The film appears not to follow her hagiography exactly. In it she is forced to marry a Roman patrician but at the wedding sits apart, and in the bedchamber tells her husband an angel is watching over her to protect her from violation. She persuades him to seek baptism and her martyrdom by the sword then follows his. {No angel in the film?] From Ivo, note recycling of designs from other Cines films as abv. Scene in house of prefect recalls paintings of the senate. Need to research how the film represents the Catacombs where Cecilia’s husband is ritualistically buried and how that representation might link into the documentation of late nineteenth-century excavations concerning the early Christian community at Rome. worth noting that the year of the release of the film was 1911, the year in which the fiftieth anniversary of the birth of the secular state was being celebrated. And worth noting that Cines was funded by the Vatican bank. Is this then a story appealing to the contemporary Church – of the victory of the Christianity faith even among the Roman elite? Noticeable that focus is on her husband & his ritualised burial, what she does to him. More melodramatic than religious. FG group asks about the Catacomb set. Is there any chance that they had filmed in the entrance of a catacomb? But looks like a set further in, ground v flat. Lighting issue.

The Martyrdom of St Cecilia, Carlo Saraceni 1610

Part of Fr postcard series on Sa Cecilia, early 20th c Maison La Bonne Presse

screenshot of catacombs in Santa Cecilia (may be part of one of the acquaducts near Rome in reality)

fields.comments:
Ivo: Indeed very little of this film remains. We published a blog post on the film with our cards. https://filmstarpostcards.blogspot.com/2019/04/the-private-life-of-helen-of-troy-1927.html

Maria: a useful book chapter in Ruby Blondell, Helen of Troy in Hollywood, 2023.
Survives in two fragments from the beginning and end of c 29 mins. Total original length c 1 hour. A comedy of modern manners and parody of epics about antiquity. Dir. Alexander Korda, First National Studios, USA. Starring Maria Corda as Helen, Lewis Stone as her husband Menelaos, and Ricardo Cortez as her lover Paris. The film claimed to be based on the 1925 novel of the same name by John Erskine. The colloquial intertitles won an Oscar, the score included popular songs of the day. Menelaos prefers fishing to his royal duties and to his wife’s social activities. They go to the theatre and have dinner the next day with the visitor Paris. In response to her husband’s lack of interest in her, Helen elopes with Paris to Troy. Menelaos looks forward to some fishing, but his generals prefer war... Menelaos welcomes victory at Troy and believes Helen now realises her place back in Sparta, but she flirts with the handsome and even younger visitor Telemachus, Prince of Ithaca. Menelaos is enthused by the possibility this provides him to go fishing after all.  [Much of the Hollywood film satirises present-day interest in clothes, fashion and shopping, while parading for audiences the female star modelling extravagant outfits in spectacular art deco settings.]
 
FG comments: consider relation of fashion designs in the film to textiles in ancient world. whereas men wear armour, women in modern-style clothing using ancient designs. note how ancient dress used architectural motifs and ornamentation that is reproduced here.

Michael Williams (after April FG): has identified the prince of Ithaca as Gordon Elliott (credit in World Film Encyclopaedia 1933). The close up below comes from Classics of the silent screen (1959). Later had roles in Westerns. MW notes also: The Private Life of Helen of Troy is such a joy to see again. The playful intertitles are quite typical of late silent films and the satirical tone makes the film a great companion to the more ‘serious’ epics often associated with antiquity, and the film could be paired with the comic shorts we saw later in the week for an entertaining programme. I found the film extract to be particularly interesting in terms of gender and sexuality. Helen clearly has her desires, and acts on them, while Menelaus seems generally indifferent to her, and certainly if there is the possibility of fishing to be had.. Ricardo Cortez as Paris seems to have been cast for his resemblance to the Latin lover type (although he was actually from New York, and seemed to be frustrated in his silent career at being cast as ‘sheik’ types in the wake of Valentino). There seems to be some visual connection to Novarro as Ben-Hur there. As was discussed on the day, the film is using cinematic types for satire, representing the ancient world through the lens of cinema as well as fashion. Gordon Elliott as Telemachus also offers a more youthful (a Narcissus?) type of male beauty. There’s also a lot to be said about queerness. There’s that line about being a ‘confirmed bachelor’ (I think with respect to Eteoneus), which is often code for gay, particularly in the early-mid 20th century, but then we have the dressmaker appear, which takes things up another notch. He’s clearly being coded as the contemporary ‘sissy’ or ‘pansy’ type, and in the late 20s there was the ‘pansy craze’ in nightclubs, theatres and on screen for sissy characters, which were seen to be a draw for urban, sophisticated audiences, and of course a source of stereotypical humour more widely. (I’ve been doing some work on fan-magazines and these discourses recently.) There’s the huge topic of the reception of the ancient world and LGBTQ+ identity over the years, so it would be good to explore that somewhere in the project’s work as an issue of increasing historical concern in terms of visibility.

fields.title: The Road to Rome or Ruin (Original) 495065
fields.synopsis: University student's film of activities and a trip to Rome. (Synopsis) "ASHTON ST FILM CORP INC PRESENTS THAT ANCIENT MONUMENT OF CINEMATIC ART THE ROAD TO ROME" (6). "This film `The Road to Rome' just scrapes through for University exhibition" (8). Travelling shot along windows of a college, through an arch to a house and doorway (13). "Produced and Photographed by" (13). A man with spectacles using a 9.5mm camera (no name given) (2 frames only). "Additional Scenes" (14). Another cameraman (no name given) (16). "THE STAFF (God Bless `em)" (17). MCU college porter (?) wearing bowler hat and smoking a cigar (21). Two students, by a crude scoreboard with `July 3 Burling v Lightfoot' chalked on it, throw objects at unseen target (25). One of the students standing by a window and counting the missing panes of glass (28). "The umpire" (29). MCU man smoking a pipe (30). "INTER-FACULTY TUG-OF-WAR - Arkitex v. Commerce" (33). Tug of war competition in college quadrangle (56). "From working drawings to working hard - during the Strike" [Presumably the General Strike of 1926] (57). Two students attempting to unload/load sacks from the hold of a ship (58). "Cowin does a `job of work' -" (59). Two students joined by a third (67). "Note the violent activity of C.E. Moore" (68). Another students joins them, he is just visible and tries to manhandle a load of sacks being lifted from the hold by a crane (72). On the quayside: a sign reading `N Victoria' in the background. A cargo ship is unloaded, watched by the students. Sacks are placed on a trolley which is hauled off by a student (80). Five students on the dockside drink from bottle (84). "A TOUR OF THE HOLT BUILDING ROWSES OUR ADMIRATION" (87). Students walking along the parapet of the Harbour Board Office in Liverpool, the Royal Liver Building can be seen in the background (98). "The Rome 1926" (sic) (100). A student at work in a studio on a set of plans. He climbs on the desk to check his work then stands up to admire it (138). "Home from home" (111). A student undresses by a sink, removing his coat, jacket and shirt and washes himself under the tap. Students at work in the studio (128). "The last lap" (138). Students in the studio waving papers (exam results ?) (150). A car in a street, some students get into the car and drive off, waved off by a crowd of students (155). "Butling (Rome Winner) 1925 in Rome..." (155). Castel San Angelo (157). Student by a wall conducts a mock archaeological excavation (168). "The Road to Rome...a more practical route..." (170). View along the Appian way (?) ruins, cypress trees and a road. Three students walk along the road, through triumphal arches and arrives at the Coliseum (210). Two students wrestle by stones in the Coliseum while another lectures in the background (215). The lecturer continues his discourse (218). Exterior view of the Coliseum (219). Ruins in the Forum (221). View across Tiber to St. Peter's (222). More ruins (225). St Peter's Square and fountain. A hand writes "THE END" (237ft). Note: Originally filmed on 9.5mm. Transferred to 16mm. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Maria: Might be good to digitise. Raises some nasty issues of class - the students break the general strike before they go off to Rome. Also British, amateur, education, architecture, travelogue. Was this ever in public distribution?

Ashton St Architectural Studio

Pathe newsreel on construction of Holt building

Maria: The opening identifies the film as an amateur production by students of architecture at the University of Liverpool in the lead up to a trip to Rome: the ‘road to Rome’ starts with a travelling shot leading up to the front door of the Architecture Studio in Ashton Street. Shots of a student cranking a 9.5mm camera and of a university porter. Student activities in Liverpool: a game involving throwing objects and counting missing panes of glass; a tug-of-war between ‘Arkitex v Commerce’; working on the docks during the Strike [presumably the General Strike of 1926], involving unloading sacks from a cargo ship; walking along the parapet of a skyscaper under construction (‘the Holt building’). The [road to] Rome 1926: Architecture students at work on their drawings in the Studio, receiving their exam results, and the winner of the Rome prize (Butling) in a car being waved off. In Rome: Castel San Angelo; making a mock archaeological discovery (the measurement & drawing of the find); walking under an arch along the Via Appia; strolling through the Forum to the Coliseum; pretending to collapse while listening to a fellow student pontificate about the ruins; the exterior view of the Coliseum, ruins in the Forum, view across the Tiber to St. Peter's, more ruins, St Peter's Square and fountain. A hand writes "THE END".

Is it Rome that is described as ‘that ancient monument of cinematic art’ (plus reference jokingly to this film itself)? When students receive their results, Butling is declared the winner of the Prize – that is the Rome Prize given out by the British School at Rome (left) to advance the education of British architects. [Details about him as a winner can be found in the BSR archive). Gradually Faculty used the prize not just to encourage good draughtsmanship and a deference to the classical tradition (through the drawing of ruins and their reconstruction – as Ostia here) but to discouraged ‘modern tendencies’.  Came to be considered reactionary by eg Le Corbusier. Le Corbusier, Towards a New Architecture (1923): ‘Rome is the damnation of the half-educated. To send architecture students to Rome is to cripple them for life.’ Although the scenes in Rome are presented with humour – they make a mock archaeological discovery and feign exhaustion at a mock lecture about classical ruins such as the Forum and the Coliseum. But ‘Road to Rome’ usually refers to the pilgrimage route established during the Middle Ages along Via Francigena that goes from Canterbury to Rome. Note image on title credit is of St Peter’s cupola. And the film ends at St Peters. The Holt / India building design influenced by Italian renaissance and included features of the American beaux-arts style. Occupied a whole block. Built between 1924 and 1932. (Herbert j Rowse one of the designers). Contrast between city of Liverpool and city of Rome. Issues of class – labourers v architecture students and strike breaking. Check article by L Campbell ‘a call to order: the rome prize’ Architectural History 32 (1989). Note G A Butling was winner of BSR prize 1925. Debates about value of the prize.

Darling: On the Rowse front - there's a body of scholarship which is reassessing how we think about British architecture in the 1920s (and 1930s) less in terms of not being modernist enough and more in how it was modern/situated in British modernity. Rowse and the Liverpool School represent a key arena in which ideas of a modern British classicism might be developed --- a place to start is Kelly & Shasore's edited volume Reconstruction (Bloomsbury, 2023), which has a historiographical foreword by me and lots of great essays; Shasore's Designs on Democracy also very helpful here.

fields.title: The Way of the Cross (Original) 24476
fields.synopsis: A Christian girl dies for her faith. Valerius, a Roman, sees Leah, a Christian girl as he watches her attend a Christian meeting. The crowd begins to mock the young girl and her followers and Valerius rescues her and takes her to her home. The jealous Gallia, lover of Valerius, sees the two together and determines to take her revenge. She gives information to Nero about the Christian girl and Leah is brought to his palace and tormented in the presence of Valerius. The next day, Nero decrees the death of all Christians. Leah receives a note from a `friend' warning her of the planned extermination and she goes into hiding with her father and young brother. One week later, in peril of his life, the brother sets out to look for food. He is seen by the Romans and captured. They torture him until he tells them of the hiding place. Valerius offers to help Leah but she refuses, saying that she must stay with her family. The soldiers come and take them away. The next day, the Christians are to be fed to the lions. In the arena, she is seen by Valerius and as her last message holds up the cross. He rushes into the prison and struggles with his conscience. Eventually, he sees that there is only one way and he decides to meet the same fate as the Christians (721ft). No main title. A group of Christians march through Rome. Meanwhile, Valerius gambles and drinks with his friends. He leaves his friends and comes upon the Christian meeting and falls in love with Leah. This is noticed by Gallia, the lover of Valerius. When the Christian group is attacked by a mob, Valerius rescues Leah and takes her home. He is followed by the slave of Gallia who has been given instructions to follow them. The next day Valerius attends a feast at Nero's palace. Gallia gives information about Leah to Nero and she is brought to the palace to be tormented. Valerius escorts her home although his advances are spurned. The next day Gallia prompts Nero to decree the death of all Christians. Valerius warns Leah and her family and they escape to the catacombs before the arrival of the soldiers. Leah's brother is sent for food. However, he is noticed by Gallia and captured. Under torture on the rack he reveals Leah's hiding place. Valerius visits the catacombs and tries to persuade Leah to leave, however her place is with her family and the Christians. As he leaves he sees the soldiers arriving and insists Leah be tried before Nero. Leah refuses to renounce her religion and she is condemned to death. She is taken to the arena. Valerius too goes to the arena where gladiators are fighting. Leah and the other Christians are led through the arena. Valerius rushes to see her but again she refuses to renounce her faith. Valerius falls to his knees and sees a vision of Leah holding her cross. He then sees Gallia holding a glass of wine for him. This is followed by a vision of the Cross and he decides to join Leah in the cell ready to be thrown to the lions pacing in the background. Leah persuades Valerius to give up his sword and another vision of the Cross appears. The Christians are then led into the arena, Leah holding aloft her cross and accompanied by Valerius (877ft). Note: German titles. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Ivo: Again a variation on The Sign of the Cross.

Michael Williams: I’ve just written something on the 1932 version of The Sign of the Cross, which is why it was on my mind!) Even the name, The Way of the Cross, seems to be trading off the success of the novel of SOTC, even as it revealingly slightly rewords it to avoid it being too blatant. Everything on screen looked very much like the iconography, characters and narrative of SOTC, including the tortured young brother of the protagonist, who equates to Stephan in the 1932 version (in the later version, his torture is powerfully rendered via off-screen sound), while it seems more visually direct here. It would be interesting to know more about the development and context of this film, especially coming relatively soon after the first production of Ben-Hur on screen. Looks like the ubiquitous reconstruction of Pollice Verso made an appearance in this film, too!

FG: Christie notes how use of water gives depth to image at court of nero (and also reflections in it). And painting of cityscape in the background. Creation of depth also with arena procession. Sophisticated in presentation of depth. Blackton came from UK. Famous for stop-action. Interesing visions at end of women Leah & Gallia rather than an angel. Note some entries are from centre back not theatrical sides (shows a world beyond the 'stage', this not theatre. The use of the cross common in evangelical contexts - eg in Salvation Army's Soldiers of the Cross.

fields.title: Though Your Sins Be As Scarlet (Original) 23447
fields.synopsis: A Roman courtesan repents of her wanton life to follow Christ. Lydia, a Roman courtesan, refuses the caresses of a Roman man. A leper passes by, seeking the Son of God. Lydia laughs at him, but later, at an orgy, she experiences pangs of remorse and dismisses the guests. Exchanging her finery for a plain garment, she preaches the forgiveness of sins to some wanton revellers, but is mocked. They fall silent as Christ passes by. Lydia is tempted to drink to Bacchus at another orgy, but again repents as Christ passes by. She sets off in search of Christ, taking her directions from three women, but arrives at Golgotha to find him crucified. An angel stands at the Tomb and Lydia kisses the robe. (564ft). (Shotlist)

fields.title: Ultimi Giorni di Pompei, Gli (Original) 49553
fields.synopsis: Set in Pompeii and based on the novel by Edward Bulwer- Lytton. Rl.1. Various shots of the ruins of Pompeii and Vesuvius (137). A reconstruction of life in old Pompeii showing artisans at work, street vendors, letter writers and the womens' baths (384). Glaucus, a young patrician, is deserted by Julia, the daughter of Diomed, a wealthy freedman. Glaucus, however, loves Ione, a patrician like himself (602). Rl.2. Arbaces, the Egyptian priest of Isis, is the guardian of Ione and her brother Apecides. Arbaces nurses a secret passion for Ione and is jealous of Glaucus. Glaucus purchases a blind slave, Nydia, who is being mistreated by her mistress. Arbaces, who wishes to gain complete power over Apecides, introduces him to a night of pleasure (476). Rl.3. Dancing girls perform and Arbaces is presented with a female slave on a platter of roses. Meanwhile, Glaucus goes to see Ione, but she refuses to see him having heard that he is amusing himself with a blind slave. He returns home where Nydia devotedly awaits him. He tells her of his love for Ione and Nydia, who secretly loves him, offers to intercede with Ione on his behalf (602). Rl.4. Apecides, disatisfied with his life, goes to see Olinthus, a Christian preacher who introduces him into the catacombs where he absorbs the new theology. Nydia, acting as Glaucus' ambassador, goes to see Ione and learns that she is in Arbaces' palace. She returns to Glaucus and, together with Apecides, hurries to the palace filled with foreboding. In the palace, Arbaces conjures up a vision for Ione in which he appears as her future husband. She tells him that ehr heart is with Glaucus. Glaucus and Apecides are in time to rescue her from violation be Arbaces who, in the ensuing struggle, is stunned by a falling statue caused by an earth tremor (850). Rl.5. Nydia, hiding her sorrow, sings to the united lovers as they sail on the river together. Theya re seen by the jealous Julia. Apecides is baptised. Julia consults Nydia about the possibility of obtaining a love philtre to administer on Glaucus. Nydia is unable to help but, following a suggestion from Julia's maid, they go together to Arbaces. Arbaces gives her a potion to induce madness instead. She accepts this but Nydia steals the potion and administers it to Glaucus herself (409). Rl.6. The horrified girl watches helplessly as Glaucus goes mad and runs amok. Apecides, inflamed by his new faith, meets Arbaces in a deserted grove and threatens to denounce him for his evil ways. Arbaces stabs him dead but is observed by Calenus, on of his priests, who is hidden in the bushes. The maddened Glaucus arrives on the scene and is denounced by Arbaces as the murderer. Glaucus is arrested for the murder despite the efforts of Olinthus who rightly suspects Arbaces of the crime (735). Rl.7. Glaucus is brought to trial and sentenced to death although his friend, Sallust, pleads his cause desperately. Apecides' body is burned according to the rites of Isis. Calenus officiates at the ceremony and afterwards demonstrates with a vision his knowledge of Arbaces' crime. Arbaces offers him untold wealth in exchange for his silence and conducts the priest to his treasure vaults. As Calenus is examining the treasure, Arbaces creeps out of the vault and locks the old man in. Nydia, who has wandered into the grounds in search of Glaucus, witnesses this further crime and hastens off for assistance but is captured by Arbaces' guards and thrown into prison (1014). Rl.8. She bribes her jailer to take a message to Sallust. Glaucus prepares to meet his end in the arena. Sallust receives Nydia's appeal for help and hastens to free her and Calenus. The spectacle commences in the arena with a gladiatorial combat. Arbaces joins the spectators who include Julis and her father. Sallust and his men release Calenus as Glaucus is led out into the arena to face a lion unarmed. Sallust arrives on the scene and denounces Arbaces. Arbaces appeals to the crowd who are divided in their opinion. There is an earthquake and Vesuvius erupts. In the ensuing panic, Sallust and Glaucus meet and Glaucus learns that Ione is a prisoner in Arbaces' palace. Forcing their way through the panic-stricken populace, they make their way to the palace and find Ione with Nydia (1004). Rl.9. The palace collapses as they make their escape. Arbaces searchers for the lovers as the destruction of Pompeii continues. Looters and thieves are at work as the the earthquake and eruption continue. Calenus is buried under falling masonry, whilst the Christians pray. Nydia guides Glaucus and Ione through the ruins but she is separated from them by the crowds. Arbaces and his guards find the lovers and as he is about to seize them, the earth opens and he falls to his death. Nydia finds them again and guides them once more through the fires and destruction. A Roman sentry remains at his post and is buried by lava. Dawn breaks and the united lovers, together with the faithful Nydia, have taken refuge on a ship in the harbour. Unable to live without Glaucus' love, Nydia slips silently away from the lovers and throws herself into the sea (1078). (7370ft) Note: The first and last reel are stencil coloured. The film has obviously been subjected to severe cuts. English titles. Note: The archive has also acquired the restoration by the Cineteca Nazionale, which is approximately 1,300ft longer. It has English intertitles and is tinted and toned, with the beginning and ending stencil coloured. (Shotlist)

fields.title: Vestale, La (Original) 377394
fields.synopsis:
The scene depicts the Forum and the Temple of Vesta. Cinna returns victorious from the Gauls and is about to receive the honours of triumph, but Acté, his fiancée, having believed him dead following false news, has entered the college of vestals and it is she who is to place the crown of triumph on the hero's forehead. Cinna, more smitten than ever, declares to Acté that he will go during the night to steal her away from the temple and make her share his destiny. The scene changes. We are in the Temple, where the great vestal is handing Acté the golden rod she is to use to fan the sacred fire. No sooner has she withdrawn than the duties of the priestess and the passion of the lover take turns to turn Acté's heart upside down. Giving in to the power of her first love, she opens the door of the temple to Cinna. At the most pathetic moment of their conversation, the fire goes out on the altar. They immediately understand the horror of their situation. The vestals arrive and find Acté fainting on the altar steps. They strip her of her sacred vestments and the great pontiff pronounces the sentence of death, covering the young girl with a black veil. She leaves, escorted by the lictors. In the catacombs, we see the pit where the priestess who broke her oath is to be buried alive. The funeral procession moves forward.Acté is preparing to sacrifice her life and is praying to the gods, when Cinna, at the head of some soldiers, appears and tries to intervene on behalf of his lover.The tumult is at its height.Suddenly, lightning bursts and rekindles the fire at the altar.Cinna pulls a fainting Acté from the grave.The pontiff yielded to the divine will manifested by such a prodigy and a final tableau showed the couple in the circus of Flora, presiding over the games and dances in honour of Venus Erycina

Source: https://www.fondation-jeromeseydoux-pathe.com/document/vestale-la/5fdd2ab8af99ca9e7f27d4ea?pageId=60cb01f76fb6ab1f3a2a5382&q=la%20vestale&pos=5. Translated from French.

[print from elsewhere available?]

Ivo: We need to check at the GP Archives site, as it is a Pathé film by Capellani. The book on Capellani, edited by AFRHC, may also tell more. Of course there was a famous opera by that name.

Maria: I have seen a version at Bois d'arcy. BFI version a bit messy.

Ivo: I have seen the GP ARchives/ CNC coloured version now. Here are my comments:

Link to the coloured version of the film La Vestale (Albert Capellani, 1908) on the site of GP Archives: https://gparchives.com/index.php?urlaction=doc&tab=showExtraits&id_doc=304505&rang=1 I had to use my password to view it. I had seen the b&w version at BFI in the past, but the colours are so essential, as the flame of Vesta, which is miraculously brought to life again, causing spectacle but also essential to the narrative. For the issue of colour in Antiquity films, this could be an interesting example. 

What is scenographically and archaeologically interesting, is that Pathé, like Cines, recycled props, even if they were more coursely made than the ones at the Roman company, which were closer to the antique originals. We thus encounter in La Vestale, but also e.g. in Messalina the same, narrowed version of a cartibulum table with lion's heads and legs as table legs, as well as the foldable braziers (which seem to lack depth). Both have only a vague resemblance to the originals, I'd say, but do remind us of them. In general, the sets use much more painted backdrops and less threedimensional sets than the Italians. Yet, Pathé, Cines, Itala and others use real curtains to play with depth by opening & clsing them and to suggest space beyond the screen.

 

Yet, the opening shot shows an intriguing painted overview of Rome on the left, combined with stairs and the terrace to the right, where there is also a suggestion of an exedra bench. The suggestion is that of a villa overlooking Rome. Here too, there is the suggestion of space but also height & depth beyond the screen.  

For a stage version of La Vestale (1908) during summer performances at the Théâtre des Arènes at Béziers, see my postcard below. This concerns the opera by Spontini.

fields.title: Virginia (Original) 23490
fields.synopsis: Virginius, a Roman soldier, leaves his daughter Virginia under the protection of her betrother, Icilius. Apiius Claudius, a patrician, tells his friend Marcus Claudius of his love for Virginia. She has refused his love and Marcus tries to claim her as his slave in order to give her to Appius, but she is saved by an indignant populace. Icilius rushes to tell Virginius who immediately leaves his camp to return to Rome to save his daughter. They ask for the protection of the Roman people and Virginius and his daughter are escorted to a tribunal presided over by Appius. The unscrupulous Appius decrees that Virginia is Marcus' slave. Preferring to see his daughter dead rather than a slave, Virginius snatches a knife and stabs Virginia in the heart (740ft). Note: English titles. The scene of the Roman camp is the same as the one in NICCOLO DE'LAPI (1909, Itala). References: Maria Adriana Prolo, Storia del cinema muto italiano Vol.1 (Milan, 1951), p.132. (Shotlist)

fields.comments:
Ivo: Very early film. I guess this is from the Biograph collection too? The Vesuvius funicular then was still relatively new (1880, reopened in 1889) and so popular it caused the hit Funiculi', funicula', now an evergreen.

Maria: The film reveals the state of the excavations at Pompeii at the start of the twentieth century, but also the hierarchies of class and nation that operated there. The camera captures Italian labourers (including children) hard at work carrying away baskets of rubble, shepherds grazing their sheep while Vesuvius looms over them, and local sedan-bearers ferrying the tourists down from the crater. When it captures a number of elegant tourists visiting Pompeii, they stare right back at the camera. Five years later, an Italian filmmaker substituted footage of the devastating 1906 eruption for the footage of the smouldering volcano from 1901. This new film disturbingly juxtaposed the serenity of visitors to ‘the City of the Dead’ with the current suffering of poor locals in the surrounding villages.

Michael Williams notes: The travelogues, particularly of Pompeii, were very striking. Vesuvius seemed to be particularly active in one of the films, with close footage of crowds watching the eruption, and probably in a way that wouldn’t be permitted today! The funicular was curious to see given that it was destroyed (I believe) in a later eruption, although I think you can see some of the rail still in situ. When talking about the ancient past the notion of the palimpsest always seems valuable in evoking all the layers, and framings, of past receptions and histories that open to view and thought. Pompeii is a gift for filmmakers in this sense, and tourists always try to frame the image of the ruins against the portentous image of Vesuvius behind, as in many of the shots in these films. These frames evoke survival at the same time as destruction and ruin, and performance in the present with those dances, and curious locals and tourists that walk before the camera. Visit to Pompeii had an odd mixture of steady and deliberate panoramic shots achieved by pans, but punctuated by people trying to get in, or out, of shot, for posterity. A mixture of being present but also of a strange quiet and emptiness in the images of the site.

Aylin: 

The short footage Visit to Pompeii, produced in 1901 by the Warwick Trading Company, showcases panoramic views of the city. Created by Charles Urban and photographed by George Albert Smith, this eight-minute film falls within the travelogue genre, as it documents a journey through the region. The moving images are organized into two distinct parts: the first part presents the ruins of Pompeii from the Forum area, while the second part features a tour of Vesuvius via the funicular. The film opens with a view of the Temple of Jupiter in the Forum, with Vesuvius visible in the background. Consistent with other visual representations across various media, Pompeii is introduced to the audience with Vesuvius as a prominent backdrop. With this iconic view, the camera rotates clockwise to reveal the façades of the Macellum, the Temple of Lares, the Temple of Vespasian, the Building of Eumachia, the Comitium, and the municipal offices. As the camera captures Via Dell’Abbondanza, it becomes possible to observe site workers carrying volcanic material in baskets on their shoulders, supervised by a man. The scene then transitions to a view of Vesuvius before moving into the next segment, which presents an elevated perspective of the city's ruined state. 

After showcasing the Basilica, the scene captures a view similar to that of the opening shot, but this frame is now filled with several people. The final building the camera surveys in the Forum is the Temple of Apollo, where site workers are visible, including a child laborer standing on the temple steps. The closing scene of the first part features a view of the ongoing excavations in 1901, likely depicting Regions 5 and 6, which were under excavation at that time. This inclusion of site workers, particularly the presence of a child laborer, highlights the human element in the archaeological process and raises questions about the socio-economic conditions of those involved in the excavations during this period. 

After views of lava taken from the edge of the mountain, the second part opens with scenes of lava at the base of Vesuvius, accompanied by footage of the funicular, demonstrating its operation. The weather appears windy and smoky, reminiscent of descriptions by Grand Tourists who utilized the funicular or sedan chairs to ascend to the mountain's cone.

Similar to 19th-century travel photographs, the film features well-dressed Victorian tourists who pose aesthetically in front of the ruins. Their elegant attire, which stands out against the dilapidated backdrop, creates an ironic contrast. Victorian ladies, in particular, often reserved specific dresses for different occasions, and the film showcases examples of their travel ensembles—relatively dark-colored dresses adorned with hats decorated with feathers or flowers. These well-dressed visitors effectively aestheticize the appearance of the ruins; for instance, two ladies pose beside the massive columns in front of the Basilica, while a group of three visitors is seen at the junction of Via Dell’Abbondanza and the Forum. The latter group poses directly at the camera, suggesting that they may have willingly participated in the film as pedestrians, engaging with the act of documenting the ruins alongside tourists. In both photography and short films, this practice not only provided a sense of scale for the ruined, roofless structures but also aimed to capture real-time, firsthand experiences of the site.

fields.title: Idylle Corinthienne 21857
fields.synopsis: DRAMA. A young shepherd drives his sheep through the courtyard of a house in Corinth. He stops to place a garland round the neck of a bust of the God of love and turns to find the object of his affections, a young servant girl, coming down the steps. They embrace and do obeisance to the god of love. As the girl dances before the statue to the music of the shepherd's flute, she is seen and bought by a Moorish slave merchant. In the slave market of Alexandria she is sold again to a rich citizen who wishes to marry her. He lavishes every attention on her but, grieving for her lost love, she will not respond. To distract her from her grief her master gives a great fete in her honour with music and dancing. Among the musicains is the shepherd who has followed his love to Alexandria. At a given moment he begins to play the tune he had played in Corinth and the slave girl immediately begins to dance. As she dances nearer to him they recognise each other and in a moment she is in his arms. Her master, in spite of his own shattered hopes, sets her at liberty and the lovers embark for Corinth. In the courtyard at Corinth they again do obeisance to the God of Love and garland him with flowers and the slave girl dances for joy (1063ft). Note: This copy has English Titles. (Shotlist)

fields.title: Boadicea (Original) 24098
fields.synopsis: Prasutagas, King of the Iceni, lies ill. One of his tribe, Caradoc, has his grain seized by Roman soldiers and his son Madoc is taken by them to the slave market when he tries to interfere. Emmelyn, the King's daughter is in love with Marcus, a Roman soldier. Caradoc arrives and tells Prasutagas what has occurred. Boadicea swears that she will not rest until her people are free. The Romans stop a Druid ceremony. Badwallon, a priest escapes back to the Iceni, arriving as the King dies. Boadicea assumes leadership of the tribe. Badwallon calls the tribe together in a glade to incite them to revolt. Marcus comes to the glade to meet Emmelyn. He is caught and is about to be killed as a spy, when Emmelyn confesses their love and his life is spared. Decianus, the Roman Governor, receives a message from Rome asking for extra tithes to be collected, simultaneously he receives the news of Prasutagas's death. He decides to collect the tithes from Boadicea. Roman soldiers are sent to collect the dead King's treasure. Boadicea objects and strikes the Commander, who orders her to be flogged and the treasure taken. Boadicea and her people vow vengeance on the Romans. Revolt spreads while the Governor entertains the envoy from Rome. The Britons attack the city and after a long fight defeat the Romans. Marcus goes for help, with Madoc in pursuit to prevent him. He catches Marcus and they fight, but Marcus overcomes Madoc. He gets help and the Romans wait for the Britons in a valley. Boadicea decides to attack but  her people are defeated. The Queen rides away from the battlefield and, with her daughters, drink poison. Marcus arrives and Emmelyn dies in his arms.

fields.comments:
Maria: Multiple elements, incomplete and out of order. Dir. Sinclair Hill, British Instructional Films, UK. Starring Phyllis Neilson-Terry as Boadicea, Lillian Hall-Davis as Emmelyn, Clifford McLaglen as Marcus. The commercial film company adopted a policy of presenting actuality and educational material in an entertaining manner. T had great success in Britain and its empire, and made a number of films during the 1920s commemorating World War One through reconstruction of significant battles. Its films (including nature films and travelogues) were released in commercial cinemas but later became available for hire in non-theatrical and school settings through its education department set up in 1925.

The titles are introduced by a shot of the statue of Boadicea on Westminster Bridge by Thomas Thorneycroft with a close up of the inscription [erected in 1902, the inscription includes part of William Cowper’s poem Boadicea, an ode (1782): ‘Regions Caesar never knew, They posterity shall sway.]. At the time, parallels were drawn between Boadicea and Queen Victoria, and the statue was considered to represent the nation and its imperial ambitions.

FG discussion: note that there were pageants of Boadicea in UK, historical reconstructions. check these. also what was the BBC doing on the radio round this time on Boadicea, and relation to suffragettes?

Michael Williams: Boadicea was also fascinating. A very striking film by the look of it, with impressive location scenes and effective use of extras. There were a lot of resources on screen there, as well as judicious use of a matte painting, but well done. It was the use of low-angled shots during the battle scenes that stood out for me, and particularly those shots of the soldiers’ feet marching towards the camera. Sinclair Hill’s next film was The Guns of Loos, which I’ve written on. That film is remarkable visually and stands up to anything on screen at that time, and knowingly used the ‘Ben-Hur shot’ for shots where the camera is buried beneath the ground for the guns of the title to ride over them. That film was also screened in Magnascope at selected venues to capitalise on such effects (a projection process that enlarged the screen optically at selected moments). There’s a nice article in Variety (5 October 1927, 10) that talks about the use of crowds and America not being able to see it. A small quote: ‘It was produced under the careful supervision of authorities in history. It does not contain crowds so large as a picture like "Ben-Hur," but it is probable that the entire population of Briton was not much larger than the "Ben-Hur" crowds, at the time A. D. 61, when the action of the Boadicea picture took place. The Boadicea picture contains crowds large enough to serve historical accuracy. It is attracting large modern crowds now wherever it Is being shown In Great Britain. Nevertheless the American public is supposed not to want to see it and they are therefore to be given no chance to see it.’ There’s also a lovely bit on it in Variety later (28 December 1927, 13): ‘"Boadicea" has historical appeal for the Britons. Miss Brenon [a New York film reviewer] considers that for the American fans the picture would be handicapped by its subordination of actors and close-ups to the spirit of pageantry, and that the hyper-patriots in such spots as Chicago might not eat up its chauvinism without gagging.’

A screenshot from the film:

The pressbook:

Ivo: Co-written by the famous Antony Asquith. Hall-Davis was a very popular actress y the time she played in this film, having played e.g. Licia in the 1924 Quo vadis?, plus various British and German films. Right after Boadcea she would act in two Hitchcock films, The Ring and The Farmer's Wife. NB Romans vs. Britons was already the background of a famous British play, Cymbeline by Shakespeare. A 1896 version by Henry irving with lavish sets by Lawrence Alma-Tadema starred Ellen Terry as Imogen, while a much publicized 1906 version starred a much younger Nora Lancaster as Imogen.

fields.comments:
IVO: Where is the original material for this film?

Michael Williams: A fantastic star vehicle for Novarro in particular (his Mexican national identity, along with his sexuality, make him a great case study for casting and star persona in the ancient epic – I’ve written a bit on this, but Ernesto Chavez article ‘Ramon is Not One of These’: Race, Class, and Sexuality in the Construction of Silent Actor Ramón Novarro’s Star Image’ is fantastic on this – could be linked to wider representational questions).

fields.title: SAN PAOLO DRAMMA BIBLICO (Original) 216917
fields.alt_titles:
The LIFE OF ST. PAUL (Alternative)

The LIFE OF SAINT PAUL (Alternative)

Der HEILIGE PAULUS (Alternative)

ST. PAUL (Alternative)
fields.synopsis: DRAMA. Biblical. Scenes from the life of St Paul the Apostle. The archive holds several versions: Paul, a merchant in Tarsus, hears of a Christian gathering in a pine forest. With a group of followers he attacks the Christians: Jacob the Younger is dragged away to be stoned. On the road to Damascus, Paul is struck blind and hears the word of the Lord asking why he persecutes Him. He is converted to Christianity and his sight restored. Years later Paul enters the Christian catacombs on the Via Appia. He converts Nero's slave girl and a Roman soldier. Paul and the Christians watch Rome burning. They emerge from the catacombs to be arrested by Roman soldiers (453ft). St. Paul is led by Roman soldiers to an execution site. He is made to kneel. [The execution is not shown]. Pilgrims bring flowers and palm leaves to the site (48ft). Note: The Archive also has DER HEILIGE PAULUS (75ft Joye 1925) dated 1910 and consisting entirely of German intertitles and corresponding to this synopsis. (Shotlist
fields.crew:
Director: Giuseppe De Liguoro, Rodolfo Kanzler
Production Company: Milano Films
Story: Adolfo Padovan

fields.print_comments:
BFI

https://collections-search.bfi.org.uk/web/Details/ChoiceFilmWorks/150220421

fields.comments:
Maria Assunta Pimpinelli at CSC Rome is interested in the possibility of restoring this film. Note much of it is set in Rome. I have taken the screenshot from a web site https://biblefilms.blogspot.com/2017/09/silent-bible-film-mystery-03-first-st.html so until I see the film I can't be use this is from it.

Ivo: I took some pictures from the Roman print. A poor preservation, by the way, copy full of tramlines (preserved without any wetgate technique) and not respecting any tinting. While the beginning could have been filmed at any birch forest of the Milanese contryside, the second half has some shots shot at the Roman Via Appia, such as the Tomb of Cecilia Metella.   . 

  

The film has a long static shot of the Fire of Rome (studio set), with Paul and the Christians watching & despairing.
The death of Paul (his beheading is not included, only suggested) was shot outside again, either near Rome or near Milan.

fields.title: Quo Vadis 42269
fields.synopsis: A story of the persecution of the Christians by the Emperor Nero. Rl.1. Nero amuses himself by watching his victims being cast into the wayer to feed his lampreys. He is attended by Petronius, his 'elegantiae arbiter', and Tigellinus, commander of the Imperial Guard. Nero signs a proclamation condemning all Christians to death. In the catacombs Peter the Apostle preaches to the Christians including Plautus, a young patrician, and his family. The corruption of the palace is reflected in the lives of the common people to whom Nero's proclamation is read. Amongst the crowd is Chilo, a charlatan philosopher. Vinicius, a young general and nephew of Petronius, returns from the wars to his uncle's home. Eunice, a slave girl devoted to Petronius, is sold some incense by Chilo who tells her that it will obtain her master's love. Vinicius relates in flashback to Petroniushow he met Lygia, the daughter of a foreign king, held by Rome as a hostage and entrusted to the care of Plautus. Petronius promises Vinicius that he will see Nero about the girl. Eunice burns the incense before a statue of her master. Nero gives Petronius a warm welcome. Tigellinus is jealous (991). Rl.2. Nero orders Lygia to be given to Vinicius. The pretorians fetch her from Plautus. Ursus, he strong and devoted slave, follows her. She is taken to the Palatine and placed in the care of Lucila, a freed woman. The two women meet Livy, the only child of the Empress Poppaea, who has escaped from his nurse. Poppaea finds them together and is struck by Lygia's beauty. Lygia is forced to attend a licentious banquet given by Nero where she meets Vinicius again. He presses his attentions on her. Nero sees them together and is attracted by the young girl (810). Rl.3. Lygia continues to repel Vinicius. Nero feigns a fatherly concern for the young girl and leads her away to his appartments. Petronius realises that the only way to save Lygia is to send for the Empress. Poppaea arrives in time to rescue Lygia from Nero's advances. Nero places Lygia once more in Vinicius' care. The banquet continues and Poppaea restores Nero to good humour by persuading him to sing. Lygia makes her way to the garden where she finds Ursus and implores him to find some way of returning her to Plautus and his family. As the Palatine orgy grows wilder, Peter prays with Plautus for Lygia to be returned...[Footage missing.] Ursus carries of Lygia as she is being escorted to the home of Vinicius. He is seen by Chilo. That night Nero has a nightmare in which Lygia appears. He asks Tigellinus to take him to a soothsayer for the dream to be interpreted (874). Rl.4. Vinicius receives the news of Lygia's abduction. Nero visits the soothsayer who foretells the burning of Rome. leaving, the Emperor sees Ursus carrying the rescued Lygia through the deserted streets. He follows and ultimately corners Lygia in her refuge. She is rescued once more by Ursus who stabs Nero in the process. Tigellinus escorts the Emperor home (766). Rl.5. Livy, the child, falls ill and dies. His nurse cries out that the Christian Lygia has bewitched him. Nero summons Vinicius and demands to know Lygia's whereabouts. When he confesses that she has been abducted, Nero falls into a rage but is restored to good humour by the wily Petronius. Petronius offers his nephew the slave girl Eunice. She begs to be allowed to stay and Petronius orders her to be whipped. Meanwhile Vinicius searches in the streets for Lygia. He is seen by Chilo who offers to guide him to her in exchange for money. Petronius witnesses the whipping of Eunice and realises her love for him. Chilo, aided by a renegade Christian, Croton, takes Vinicius to the catacombs where Lygia and other Christians are hiding. Ursus rushes to ehr defence, sends Chilo and Croton flying and wounds Vinicius. Lygia nurses him (981). Rl.6. Vinicius begs Lygia's forgiveness. She realises that sheloves him and prays for his conversion. Nero sends Petronius an invitation to hear him recite his new poem on the burning of Troy.Chilo arrives on the scene as the restored Vinicius returns. Vinicius orders him to be whipped and Chilo vows vengeance. Nero, determined to surpass The Iliad, recites his poem. He is acclaimed by the sycophantic courtiers but Petronius tells him the poem lacks fire. Nero looks at Rome and the watchful Tigellinus grasps his meaning. Two days later a fire is started. Nero is enraptured. Vinicius searches for Lygia (807). Rl.7. Petronius is unable to hide his indignation and his denunciation of Nero is overheard by Tigellinus. As Nero plays his lyre panic fills the streets and the populace make their way to the Palatine crying for vengeance on the arsonists. Vinicius saves Plautus' wife and child from their collapsing house but is unable to find Lygia. At the Palatine the crowds break through the guards and cry for Nero. Nero looks around desperately for a scapegoat. Chilo creeps to the throne and suggests the Christians. Nero announces to the threatening crowds that they are responisble. Christians are immediately arrested wholesal. Petronius advises Vinicius to save Lygia. Peter yields to his followers' advise and leaves Rome. On his way he meets Christ who asks him "Quo vadis?" Peter returns. The Christians are cast into prison, including Lygia, Ursus, Plautus and his family. The martyrdom of the Christians commences: they are thrown into the arena and fed to the lions. Nero and Poppaea, attended by Petronius and Vinicius, watch the massacre. Nero tells Vinicius that he has a surprise for him. Petronius tries to console his nephew by telling him that Lygia is not among the prisoners. He receives a message that the mutinous legions of Spain and Gault have proclaimed Galba emperor and are marching on Rome. More Christians are sent into the arena but Lygia is kept behind on Nero's orders. Plautus is separated from his family but escapes from the lions by climbing into the evergreen decorations (1213). Rl.8. Petronius hands the message from Gaul to Nero who immediately sends him to his house. Anticipating Nero's order, Petronius invites his friends to a feast and, after reading alound a scurilous document addressed to Nero, asks a surgeon to open his veins. Eunice dies with him. Plautus' wife is lashed to a chariot with her child. The child is rescued by Ursus but the mother is dragged around the arena in a chariot race with the other Christians similarly treated. She manages to gain control of the chariot and the crowds are so impressed with her bravery that the crowd cry for ehr release and she is reunited with her son. The revolting legionaries enter the city as Ursus is led into the arena to fight a bull to which Lygia has been bound. Nero anxiously awaits the outcome and is furious when Ursus kills the bull and releases Lygia. The crowd once again demand that she be released. Vinicius rushes to Lygia and joins in the pleas for mercy. Nero refuses and the enraged crowd take control as Galba's men enter the arena. Tigellinus grabs Nero and takes him to the Palatine whilst Vinicius leads the mobs in pursuit. Two Christian slaves take pity on the panic-stricken Emperor and lead him to Plautus who has been reunited with his family and the other Christians. Ursus wants to revenge himself on Nero but Lygia pleads tolerance. Plautus sets Nero free and he takes refuge in a peasant's cottage. As Galba's troops approach he reluctantly takes his own life, aided by the peasant. Lygia and Vinicius are married by Peter (1100). (7542ft) Note: English intertitles. Sections are obviously missing, particularly from reel 3. (Shotlist)

fields.title: The Ancient Roman
fields.synopsis: Comedy. 3 archaeologists discover a tomb and liberate an ancient Roman soldier into modern Rome.
fields.print_comments:
restricted access

Ivo: According to Eric le Roy, in the Filmographie of Le Film d'Art, this was a Pathé production of 1910, entitled Le Reveil du Romain. Length 365 m. "Synopsis : « Dans ce film, l’auteur met en scène un Romain, qui endormi depuis quelques siècles, se réveille en pleine Rome moderne et parcourt avec surprise et ravissement la ville la plus célèbre de l’Univers, par ses monuments et ses souvenirs historiques. » [Dépôt légal BnF, 4 col 4 (4881)]." See https://journals.openedition.org/1895/4086. "Note : scénario conforme à la vue BnF, 4° col 4 (1567)."

Ivo (29-10-/24): According to Federico Striuli there are two films: the Italian version dating of July 1909 and the Pathé version of 1910, which is slightly different and a reworking of the Italian version. 

No Info found in FIAF
fields.comments: Being restored by Federico Striuli. He says: The BFI print is indeed a nitrate element, but very incomplete and, possibly, heavily worn and even with some nitrate decay. Our restoration is, on the other hand, based on a complete element, with no decay.  Right now, we are working simultaneously on several titles, and despite this restoration has been finalized, I have no screener at the moment. Are you planning to come to Rome or to the Giornate film festival in Pordenone this October? If yes, I can try to show it to you by then.  Maria Assunta Pimpinelli working on this and another Cines comedy (not in BFI).

fields.title: Amour d’esclave
fields.synopsis: Ancient Athens. Polymos falls in love with the slave Chloë. No main title. Polymos is bored by the attention of merchants and their rich goods. He dismisses them angrily. His wife, Chrysis, sends for the slave girl Chloë to dance for Polymos. Polymos is much taken with the dance and the dancer and goes to embrace her only to be separated by his wife who dismisses Chloë. However, once Chrysis has gone, Polymos follows Chloë into the garden. There he observes her giving flowers in an offering to the God of nature, Pan. She kisses the statue. Polymos makes his presence known and they embrace in a long kiss. They part blowing kisses to one another. Polymos retires to his bed. Chloë enters his quarters and places some perfume on a dying fire which then bursts into flame. Polymos dreams of Chloë dancing with a corp de ballets and veils (291-443). Polymos awakens and embraces Chloë. However, Chrysis enters the room and orders Chloë to be taken to the dungeons. Once there, Chloë is offered poison or death by whipping on a post. She chooses the poison and drinks it. Polymos enters the cell and stops the guard from whipping Chloë. She dances for Polymos once more but dies in his arms. He realizes she has taken poison and drinks it himself to be united in death with her. His wife enters and is stricken by his death (632ft). Note: English intertitles
fields.comments:
Already digitized for live performance (screened Bloomsbury 2009)

Ivo: Has been preserved in color by Eye Filmmuseum.

Maria: discussion by Lewinsky in 1895, viewable in Foundation JS-P, so we should definitely discuss, but perhaps save it for the Eye focus group.

Pantelis @ FG: a prestigious production for Pathé that year. Three autonomous tableaux (lots of action within the frame) but more modern approach to narration at end (shots outside and inside). Acting appears to be trying to emulate high art of theatre / pantomime, because seems more extreme than other films of 1900s. They are delivering lines (is that naturalistic, or showing what we are missing?) Was screened in Montreal in May 1907 as 'talking picture' with live dialogue (so concealed actors rather than a lecture, enhancing atmosphere of experiencing a dream rather than a lesson) and a score composed especially for it. At Nationoscope. [suggests film stood out, worth investing in]. Q of how BFI copy compares to Amsterdam and LoC versions re colour.Wheel of rainbow colours in the blue-toned dream dance sequence.

LoCongree. Photo by Barbara Flueckiger.poster

fields.title: NOTES- LONDON FOCUS MEETING
fields.content:
Observations from Focus Group April 24

General

Metaphors of reception:

Concept of palimpsest valuable in invoking layers. framings of past receptions (used by Aylin) eg framing ruins of Pompeii against Vesuvius

Aylin’s mise-en-abyme – metaphor for reception and the project, series of frames (historical, archaeological, artistic, cinematic)

Discourse of authenticity:

What does a representation need to seem authentic (monumentality, decoration, vegetation & costume)? What is the grammar of representing antiquity? Note also how sometimes invocation of a classical setting is quite loose (mixing G&R together).

Location shooting; use of ruins (providing a patina of pastness) & issues of temporality. 

motifs like Greek tetraktys (swastika) or the Roman eagle - what do they mean at different times. 

Design of antiquity:

Aylin uses language of ‘deconstructing the filmic archive’ - elements of space, architecture & daily life within films (mise en scene, public spaces & monuments, domestic architecture, decorative elements, representations of daily life [rituals & themes]) & external influences on their creation (inc scientific printed media, stage shows, literary works & visual media).

What happens to spatial layouts when the camera moves , how are spaces utilised in narrative (eg entry into private areas)?

Architecture

Note use of antiquity in cinema architecture & of scenography in the construction of Pompeian housing and how some films draw on contemporary architecture (like art deco in 1920s).

Excavations:

how closely are the films related to current excavations and publicity around finds. do the films attract people to the excavations? eg Pompeii films using objects in the Naples Museum. Cabiria using items from Turin museum and Louvre. and to understanding of space public and domestic.

Sets & Objects:

a lot of emphasis given to sets, foregrounded over narrative sometimes. solidity of props recycled by Cines. based on excavations & paintings. relation to theatre props and sets? Designers: did any architects take up film making, not just painters? Did filmmakers consult architectural magazines for their designs? [SAHGB]. How much do we know about the art departments of film studios.

People

spaces are now populated, occupied. but with people living 19th century narratives. what about gestures & movements like Roman salute. need to make users aware that what you see is not what it was like however accurate the space and the objects are. (eg about race, women, slavery, romantic stories).

Cinema techniques / intermediality

Intermediality:

Lynda Nead on crossovers between painting, photography & cinemaColour

movement of colour in film often seen as a sign of modernity. films sold as B&W or colour (much more expensive).

Theatre 

relations to current theatre & pantomime. consider where actors emote, or speak lines that cannot be heard. Work of intertitles. use of lecturer (a lesson), or concealed actors (a performance). Cf mime artist in L’Enfant du Paradis. Is cinema engaging more or less than theatre w classics?

Music

consider what difference sound makes. Sometimes within films they reconstruct ancient instruments but otherwise not researching ‘ancient’ music.

Special effects

use of visions, compare to how magic lanterns make the invisible visible in order to stimulate belief in audiences. also opportunity to draw attention to the apparatus of projection.

Camera techniques

eg where pans were used, or dolly, or high angles. how camera supports development of a cinematic language of antiquity. as proxy for spectator, shows where you are being positioned.

Stardom:

Eg Novarro in BH.

Themes & Genres

colonialism / imperialism

to what extent do these films sustain or stimulate particular ideas of antiquity eg myths of empire.

Whiteness/race:

Statues presented as white rather than polychrome; black male slaves often become part of set (framing a doorway, observing action), do we know who these actors were? How recruited? Can they escape the stereotype in the way they perform the slave role? How are these black slaves related to painting or theatre? And to our understanding of antiquity? Use of blackface. Assumption in American films that slaves were black. Issue of how race in these films imagined in modern terms, films retroject into ancient world modern ideas.

Gender & sexuality:

Queerness of Private Life of Helen, reception of ancient world in relation to queer identities

Parody:

Note copies & parodies exist within antiquity; Films satirising cinema’s types (eg Helen satirising types of male hero or Lupino Lane on masculine hero); representing ancient world through lens of cinema; parodies are knowing about ancient past as framed by cinema.

Database / website

Sources: For classical texts eg Sophocles Antigone, we can provide links to the Perseus site. texts in Project Gutenberg.

Publicity: Postcards & trade advertisements useful - we could concentrate on British ads. eg Kineweekly (for Fall of Troy), Bioscope. sometimes tell us what theatre managers said as well as guide to selling points of antiquity films in UK.

Objects & sculpture - can tags be provided to find them across films. Could we use medium recognition software here?

Spaces & places - How can a user trace where an arena appears or a temple? Could do eg a photo gallery.

[We could ask classics or architecture students to do some of this work. As projects in their programmes.]

Could offer some mechanism for users to annotate or comment (comment - eg disqus for users to offer comments and us to act upon them). Maybe even before launch. Grazia Ingravalle suggesting could pilot annotation with some users. Check  Media Ecology Dartmouth (too old?, problem of backwards compatibility). Danish Film Archive - Thomas Christenson (where asking users to write in with suggestions of eg identification). 

Problems of longevity. consider ways in which smaller elements of the website could be packaged for use in other ways (beyond teaching resources). perhaps put things on Youtube because it is an enduring platform. Create an e-book? Ensure the conference papers are open access.

Copyright. Can use materials like paintings if had voiceovers or annotations.

Can ask for an AHRC extension if any money left to extend the project beyond its end date, so long as no additional cost to AHRC.

Teaching resources

create an ontology for the resources to indicate what age group they are for.

make sure users of resources are aware that what you see is not an accurate depiction of the ancient world.

consult Bartlett. esp MA Cinema & Architecture. Lou Pearson. film making element in their MA. Penelope has written about what is an architecture film essay.

Website to offer in resources some annotated clips, identifying monuments or objects. Grazia Ingravalle - says provide teachers with opportunity to annotation first versions of resources, helps produce metadata.

provide architectural models? 

users of resources could include: key stage 3 & 4 students at school, looks at bks 1 & 2

Cambridge Latin Course covers bk 1 Pompeii, bk 2 Isis & bk 3 Roman Britain. Perhaps create really short clips, and collaborate with CLC to make clips that correspond with the Latin to enliven the course. check myclc.co.uk Caroline Bristow.

set designers. media students. as well as classics and architecture students. film schools for the film making resource?

Museum exhibition

find analogue (material) connections between the Soane collection & the films on show. eg guidebooks (with multiples of same monument). film posters. if didn’t show the films at Garden Cinema could have them at Southbank?

Check RIBA architecture library catalogue for British photographers who went to sites. Might be able to show their photos in exhibition?

Public screenings

there is a 1912 cinema in Brighton.

Conference

what about film schools? should invite someone to conference, eg ex head of Norwegian film school.
