Problems of longevity. consider ways in which smaller elements of the website could be packaged for use in other ways (beyond teaching resources). perhaps put things on Youtube because it is an enduring platform. Create an e-book? Ensure the conference papers are open access.

Copyright. Can use materials like paintings if had voiceovers or annotations.

Can ask for an AHRC extension if any money left to extend the project beyond its end date, so long as no additional cost to AHRC.

Teaching resources

create an ontology for the resources to indicate what age group they are for.

make sure users of resources are aware that what you see is not an accurate depiction of the ancient world.

consult Bartlett. esp MA Cinema & Architecture. Lou Pearson. film making element in their MA. Penelope has written about what is an architecture film essay.

Website to offer in resources some annotated clips, identifying monuments or objects. Grazia Ingravalle - says provide teachers with opportunity to annotation first versions of resources, helps produce metadata.

provide architectural models? 

users of resources could include: key stage 3 & 4 students at school, looks at bks 1 & 2

Cambridge Latin Course covers bk 1 Pompeii, bk 2 Isis & bk 3 Roman Britain. Perhaps create really short clips, and collaborate with CLC to make clips that correspond with the Latin to enliven the course. check myclc.co.uk Caroline Bristow.

set designers. media students. as well as classics and architecture students. film schools for the film making resource?

Museum exhibition

find analogue (material) connections between the Soane collection & the films on show. eg guidebooks (with multiples of same monument). film posters. if didn’t show the films at Garden Cinema could have them at Southbank?

Check RIBA architecture library catalogue for British photographers who went to sites. Might be able to show their photos in exhibition?

Public screenings

there is a 1912 cinema in Brighton.

Conference

what about film schools? should invite someone to conference, eg ex head of Norwegian film school.

fields.title: ORIGINAL RESEARCH QUESTIONS
fields.content:
RESEARCH QUESTIONS & COMPARATIVE APPROACH

(1) Content & Style. How was classical antiquity represented in silent cinema in terms of content
and style? What were its distinctive features? On what sources did the films draw? How did its representation
change over time? (2) Context. How were these films situated in relation to the periods and the societies of
their production, exhibition and consumption and how did they speak to contemporary concerns (of national
identity, gender and sexuality, class, religion or ethnicity)? (3) Function. Why were claims made in the early
twentieth century that cinema was an especially effective education regarding the classical world? What
counterclaims were made that cinema vulgarised and distorted that world? How did this debate about
cinematic antiquity vary between nations and across time? (4) Value. How can these films educate us now
about cinema and the classical world and the ways in which our understanding of the classical world and the
conditions of cinema have altered over the last one hundred years? By answering these questions, Museum
of Dreams will establish a better understanding of both the modern reception of classical antiquity and the
transnational history and cultural status of silent cinema. By focusing on the BFI holdings, the project will also
situate the UK firmly within the global network that produced, exhibited, consumed, and curated the classical antiquity films of the early twentieth century, and establish for those films an important educational legacy
in the twenty-first century.

We will utilise the project’s digital resource to investigate our RQs concerning Content & Style
and Context in both interdisciplinary and comparative terms. In prior studies, we have observed that
differences occur between (a) the type of antiquity film made according to country of production; (b) prints
of the same film according to country of exhibition; (c) representations of classical v. other antiquities and of
ancient Greece v. Rome; and (d) technological, aesthetic and ideological strategies of representation over
the course of the silent era. MoD’s comparative approach to our corpus will provide deeper knowledge of
variations across place and time in both the modern investment in the classical past and the status of cinema
in culture. Our highly innovative, bi-focal consideration of pedagogy (our RQs concerning contemporary
Function and current Value) also challenges orthodox, linear chronologies in which silent antiquity films
remain unwatched in the archive. Instead, it gives them fresh purpose today.

fields.title: Teaching Resources | EXAMPLES
fields.material:
FROM Aurore Spiers, Assistant Professor, Film & Media Studies School of Performance, Visualization & Fine Arts Texas A&M University

At the Domitor conference in Vienna in June 2024, I gave a presentation on the rewards and challenges of teaching early cinema within the context of our current digital ecologies. My goals were to study, following Caroline Golum in her essay on TikTok and the “cinema of attractions” (Mubi Notebook, 2021), when early cinema overlaps with contemporary media; and to examine how digital technologies and practices like editing software, crowdsourcing, video sharing, and social media have informed our pedagogical engagement with early cinema. To achieve these goals, I was interested in gathering information—through a brief survey—on how you teach early cinema to students in the classroom. 

 

The survey I circulated received many interesting responses, and I’m grateful to those among you who already participated. My presentation at the Domitor conference also sparked a rich conversation about early film pedagogy. Thank you to the conference participants for sharing their thoughts and feedback. I want to use this momentum to share the survey again. Please consider filling it out if you haven’t done so already: https://forms.gle/XQAzMj3dDCtVTTRH7 

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdk21CqpWf3YUrGKhH-nG-KPPVxp3zPyxV5M_bXJ3ELfhWoYw/viewform?pli=1

This survey, which includes 12 questions, asks about course content and pedagogical strategies, from lesson plans to assignments. I will analyze the responses and continue to share them with you soon (probably in the form of a special journal issue). Unless you wish to remain anonymous, your work will be cited and credited as your own in my report. My hope is that we can learn from each other and brainstorm new ways to teach early cinema in film and media classes today. I am grateful in advance for your willingness to collaborate with me on this project.

 

Cinema Year Zero: Tik Tok and the Grammar of Silent Film by Caroline Golum 

https://mubi.com/en/notebook/posts/cinema-year-zero-tik-tok-and-the-grammar-of-silent-film
